page.title: Reactive oxygen species production in marine microalgae

revision.comment: Added free to read link in citations with [[WP:OABOT|OAbot]] #oabot
revision.text:
{{technical|date=April 2013}}
All living cells produce [[reactive oxygen species]] (ROS) as a byproduct of metabolism. ROS are reduced oxygen intermediates that include the [[superoxide]] radical (O<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup>) and the [[hydroxyl radical]] (OH•), as well as the non-radical species [[hydrogen peroxide]] (H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>). These ROS are important in the normal functioning of cells, playing a role in signal transduction<ref name="Cadenas">{{cite journal |pmid=2673022 |year=1989 |last1=Cadenas |first1=E |title=Biochemistry of oxygen toxicity |volume=58 |pages=79–110 |doi=10.1146/annurev.bi.58.070189.000455 |journal=Annual Review of Biochemistry}}</ref><ref name="Fridovich_a">{{cite journal |pmid=9510531 |year=1998 |last1=Fridovich |first1=I |title=Oxygen toxicity: A radical explanation |volume=201 |issue=Pt 8 |pages=1203–9 |journal=The Journal of Experimental Biology}}</ref> and the expression of transcription factors.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/science.279.5357.1718 |title=Activation of the OxyR Transcription Factor by Reversible Disulfide Bond Formation |year=1998 |last1=Zheng |first1=M. |journal=Science |volume=279 |issue=5357 |pages=1718–21 |pmid=9497290 |last2=Aslund |first2=F |last3=Storz |first3=G |bibcode=1998Sci...279.1718Z }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=12115731 |year=2002 |last1=Martindale |first1=JL |last2=Holbrook |first2=NJ |title=Cellular response to oxidative stress: Signaling for suicide and survival |volume=192 |issue=1 |pages=1–15 |doi=10.1002/jcp.10119 |journal=Journal of Cellular Physiology}}</ref> However, when present in excess, ROS can cause damage to proteins, lipids and DNA by reacting with these biomolecules to modify or destroy their intended function. As an example, the occurrence of ROS have been linked to the aging process in humans, as well as several other diseases including [[Alzheimer's disease|Alzheimer's]], [[rheumatoid arthritis]], [[Parkinson's disease|Parkinson's]], and some cancers.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0921-8734(92)90030-S |title=Free radical theory of aging |year=1992 |last1=Harman |first1=Denham |journal=Mutation Research/DNAging |volume=275 |issue=3–6 |pages=257–266}}</ref> Their potential for damage also makes reactive oxygen species useful in direct protection from invading pathogens,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/s0981-9428(03)00135-9 |title=The antioxidant systems vis-à-vis reactive oxygen species during plant–pathogen interaction |year=2003 |last1=De Gara |first1=Laura |last2=De Pinto |first2=Maria C. |last3=Tommasi |first3=Franca |journal=Plant Physiology and Biochemistry |volume=41 |issue=10 |pages=863–870}}</ref> as a defense response to physical injury,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0048-4059(85)90044-X |title=NADPH-dependent O<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup> generation in membrane fractions isolated from wounded potato tubers inoculated with Phytophthora infestans |year=1985 |last1=Doke |first1=N |journal=Physiological Plant Pathology |volume=27 |issue=3 |pages=311–322}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1432-1033.1991.tb16312.x |title=The superoxide-generating oxidase of phagocytic cells. Physiological, molecular and pathological aspects |year=1991 |last1=Morel |first1=Francoise |last2=Doussiere |first2=Jacques |last3=Vignais |first3=Pierre V. |journal=European Journal of Biochemistry |volume=201 |issue=3 |pages=523–46 |pmid=1657601}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=8574346 |year=1995 |last1=Bolwell |first1=GP |last2=Butt |first2=VS |last3=Davies |first3=DR |last4=Zimmerlin |first4=A |title=The origin of the oxidative burst in plants |volume=23 |issue=6 |pages=517–32 |journal=Free Radical Research |doi=10.3109/10715769509065273}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1006/pmpp.1997.0129 |title=Mechanisms for the generation of reactive oxygen species in plant defence – a broad perspective |year=1997 |last1=Bolwell |first1=G.P. |last2=Wojtaszek |first2=P. |journal=Physiological and Molecular Plant Pathology |volume=51 |issue=6 |pages=347–366}}</ref> and as a mechanism for stopping the spread of bacteria and viruses by inducing [[programmed cell death]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/35081161 |title=Plant pathogens and integrated defence responses to infection |year=2001 |last1=Dangl |first1=Jeffery L. |last2=Jones |first2=Jonathan D. G. |journal=Nature |volume=411 |issue=6839 |pages=826–33 |pmid=11459065|bibcode=2001Natur.411..826D }}</ref>
Reactive oxygen species are present in low concentrations in seawater and produced primarily through the photolysis of organic and inorganic matter.<ref name="KeiberDavid">{{cite book |last1=Kieber |first1=David J. |last2=Peake |first3=Norman M. |last3=Scully |title=UV effects in aquatic organisms and ecosystems |year=2003 |publisher=Royal Society of Chemistry |location=Cambridge |isbn=9780854043019 |pages=251–76 |editor=E. Walter Helbling |chapter=Chapter 8: Reactive oxygen species in aquatic ecosystems}}</ref> However, the biological production of ROS, generated through algal photosynthesis and subsequently 'leaked' to the environment, can contribute significantly to concentrations in the water column.<ref name="Palenik">{{cite journal |last1=Palenik |first1=Brian |last2=Zafiriou |first2=O. C. |last3=Morel |first3=F. M. M. |title=Hydrogen Peroxide Production by a Marine Phytoplankter |journal=Limnology and Oceanography |publisher=American Society of Limnology and Oceanography |volume=32 |issue=6 |jstor=2836931 |pages=1365–1369 |doi=10.4319/lo.1987.32.6.1365 |year=1987|bibcode=1987LimOc..32.1365P }}</ref><ref name="Palenik_a">{{cite journal |doi=10.4319/lo.1988.33.6_part_2.1606 |title=Dark production of H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> in the Sargasso Sea |year=1988 |last1=Palenik |first1=B. |last2=Morel |first2=F. M. M. |journal=Limnology and Oceanography |volume=33 |issue=6, part 2 |pages=1606–11}}</ref><ref name="Wong">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0399-1784(02)00006-3 |title=The decomposition of hydrogen peroxide by marine phytoplankton |year=2003 |last1=Wong |first1=George T.F. |last2=Dunstan |first2=William M. |last3=Kim |first3=Dong-Beom |journal=Oceanologica Acta |volume=26 |issue=2 |pages=191–198}}</ref> Although there is very little information on the biological generation of ROS in marine surface waters, several species of marine phytoplankton have recently been shown to release significant amounts of ROS into the environment.<ref name="Oda">{{cite journal |pmid=9362113 |year=1997 |last1=Oda |first1=T. |last2=Nakamura |first2=A. |last3=Shikayama |first3=M. |last4=Kawano |first4=I. |last5=Ishimatsu |first5=A. |last6=Muramatsu |first6=T. |title=Generation of reactive oxygen species by raphidophycean phytoplankton |volume=61 |issue=10 |pages=1658–62 |journal=Bioscience, Biotechnology, and Biochemistry |doi=10.1271/bbb.61.1658}}</ref><ref name="Marshall_a">{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/plankt/24.11.1231 |title=Photosynthesis does influence superoxide production in the ichthyotoxic alga ''Chattonella marina'' (Raphidophyceae) |year=2002 |last1=Marshall |first1=J.A. |journal=Journal of Plankton Research |volume=24 |issue=11 |pages=1231–36}}</ref> This ROS has the potential to harm nearby organisms,<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=925614 |year=1977 |last1=Nathan |first1=CF |last2=Root |first2=RK |title=Hydrogen peroxide release from mouse peritoneal macrophages: Dependence on sequential activation and triggering |volume=146 |issue=6 |pages=1648–62 |pmc=2181906 |journal=The Journal of Experimental Medicine |doi=10.1084/jem.146.6.1648}}</ref><ref name="Yang">{{cite journal |doi=10.3354/dao023101 |title=Oxygen-radical-mediated effects of the toxic phytoplankter ''Heterosigma carterae'' on juvenile rainbow trout ''Oncorhynchus mykiss'' |year=1995 |last1=Yang |first1=CZ |last2=Albright |first2=LJ |last3=Yousif |first3=AN |journal=Diseases of Aquatic Organisms |volume=23 |pages=101–8}}</ref> and, in fact, has been implicated as the cause of massive fish, bacteria, and protist mortalities.<ref name="IshimatsuAtsushi">{{cite journal |last1=Ishimatsu |first1=Atsushi |last2=Oda |first2=Tatsuya |last3=Yoshida |first3=Makoto |last4=Ozaki |first4=Masayori |title=Oxygen radicals are probably involved in the mortality of Yellowtail by ''Chattonella marinas'' |journal=Fisheries Science |volume=62 |year=1996 |pages=836–837}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1529-8817.2006.00256.x |title=Viral Infection of Emiliania Huxleyi (Prymnesiophyceae) Leads to Elevated Production of Reactive Oxygen Species |year=2006 |last1=Evans |first1=Claire |last2=Malin |first2=Gillian |last3=Mills |first3=Graham P. |last4=Wilson |first4=William H. |journal=Journal of Phycology |volume=42 |issue=5 |pages=1040–47}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.3354/ame01570 |title=Reactive oxygen species are linked to the toxicity of the dinoflagellate Alexandrium spp. To protists |year=2012 |last1=Flores |first1=HS |last2=Wikfors |first2=GH |last3=Dam |first3=HG |journal=Aquatic Microbial Ecology |volume=66 |issue=2 |pages=199–209}}</ref>
== Chemical background ==
In sea water, ROS can be generated through abiotic as well as biotic processes, among which are the radiolysis and photolysis of water molecules and cellular respiration. According to a model proposed by Fan<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.marchem.2008.01.005 |title=Photochemical and biochemical controls on reactive oxygen and iron speciation in the pelagic surface ocean |year=2008 |last1=Fan |first1=Song-Miao |journal=Marine Chemistry |volume=109 |pages=152–164}}</ref> for the prediction of ROS in surface waters, the biochemistry mediated by phytoplankton may be just as important for the production of ROS as photochemistry. Biological ROS is often synthesized in mitochondrial membranes, as well as the endoplasmic reticulum of animals, plants, and some bacteria.<ref name="Pmid">{{cite journal |pmid=11337409 |year=2001 |last1=Moller |first1=IM |title=Plant Mitochondria and Oxidative Stress: Electron Transport, NADPH Turnover, and Metabolism of Reactive Oxygen Species |volume=52 |pages=561–591 |doi=10.1146/annurev.arplant.52.1.561 |journal=Annual Review of Plant Physiology and Plant Molecular Biology}}</ref><ref name="Lesser">{{cite journal |pmid=16460273 |year=2006 |last1=Lesser |first1=MP |title=Oxidative stress in marine environments: Biochemistry and physiological ecology |volume=68 |pages=253–78 |doi=10.1146/annurev.physiol.68.040104.110001 |journal=Annual Review of Physiology}}</ref> In addition, chloroplasts and the organelles peroxisomes and glyoxysomes are also sites for the generation of ROS.<ref name="Pmid" /><ref name="Lesser" /><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=11286918 |year=2001 |last1=Corpas |first1=FJ |last2=Barroso |first2=JB |last3=Del Río |first3=LA |title=Peroxisomes as a source of reactive oxygen species and nitric oxide signal molecules in plant cells |volume=6 |issue=4 |pages=145–50 |journal=Trends in Plant Science |doi=10.1016/S1360-1385(01)01898-2}}</ref> The ROS most likely released to the environment are those produced at the cell surface as electrons get "leaked" from the respiratory chain and react with molecular oxygen, O<sub>2</sub>.<ref name="Marshall">{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s00227-005-1596-7 |title=Superoxide production by marine microalgae |year=2005 |last1=Marshall |first1=Judith-Anne |last2=Salas |first2=Miguel |last3=Oda |first3=Tatsuya |last4=Hallegraeff |first4=Gustaaf |journal=Marine Biology |volume=147 |issue=2 |pages=533–540}}</ref> The products of this subsequent reduction of molecular oxygen are what are referred to as reactive oxygen species. Thus, the production of ROS is in direct proportion to the concentration of O<sub>2</sub> in the system, with increases of O<sub>2</sub> leading to higher production of ROS.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=3010832 |year=1986 |last1=Jamieson |first1=D |last2=Chance |first2=B |last3=Cadenas |first3=E |last4=Boveris |first4=A |title=The relation of free radical production to hyperoxia |volume=48 |pages=703–19 |doi=10.1146/annurev.ph.48.030186.003415 |journal=Annual Review of Physiology}}</ref> There are three main reactive oxygen species: the superoxide anion (O<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup>), hydrogen peroxide (H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>), and the hydroxyl radical (OH•). The superoxide anion is formed directly from the one-electron reduction of molecular oxygen.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/bi00833a050 |title=One-electron reactions in biochemical systems as studied by pulse radiolysis. II. Riboflavine |year=1969 |last1=Land |first1=Edward J. |last2=Swallow |first2=Albert J. |journal=Biochemistry |volume=8 |issue=5 |pages=2117–25 |pmid=5785230}}</ref> Hydrogen peroxide is then formed from the [[disproportionation]] of the superoxide anion. This reaction occurs very quickly in seawater. Next, the reduction of hydrogen peroxide yields the hydroxyl radical, H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>↔2OH•, which can then get reduced to the hydroxyl ion and water.<ref name="Cadenas" /> However, the presence of reactive oxygen species in marine systems is hard to detect and measure accurately, for a number of reasons. First, ROS concentrations are generally low (nanomoles) in seawater. Second, they may react with other hard to identify molecules that occur in low quantities, resulting in unknown products. Finally, they are (for the most part) transient intermediates, having lifetimes as little as microseconds.<ref name="Blough">{{cite book |last1=Blough |first1=Neil |last2=Zepp |first2=Richard G. |title=Active oxygen in chemistry |year=1995 |publisher=Blackie Acad. & Professional |location=London |isbn=9780751402926 |editor=Christopher S. Foote |chapter=Chapter 8: Reactive oxygen species in natural waters}}</ref>
===Superoxide production===
According to Blough & Zepp,<ref name="Blough" /> superoxide is one of the hardest reactive oxygen species to quantify because it is present in low concentrations: 2×10<sup>−12</sup> M in the open ocean and up to 2×10<sup>−10</sup>M in coastal areas. The main sources of biological superoxide in the ocean come from the reduction of oxygen at the cell surface and metabolites released into the water.<ref name="Marshall" /><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.4319/lo.2005.50.4.1172 |title=Extracellular production of superoxide by marine diatoms: Contrasting effects on iron redox chemistry and bioavailability |year=2005 |last1=Kustka |first1=Adam B. |last2=Shaked |first2=Yeala |last3=Milligan |first3=Allen J. |last4=King |first4=D. Whitney |last5=Morel |first5=François M. M. |journal=Limnology and Oceanography |volume=50 |issue=4 |pages=1172–80|bibcode=2005LimOc..50.1172K }}</ref> In marine systems, superoxide most often acts as a one-electron reductant, but it can also serve as an oxidant and may increase the normally slow oxidation rates of environmental compounds.<ref name="KeiberDavid" /><ref name="Blough" /> Superoxide is very unstable, with between 50 and 80% of its concentration of anions spontaneously disproportionating to hydrogen peroxide. At its peak, this reaction occurs with a rate constant on the order of 2.2×10<sup>4</sup> – 4.5×10<sup>5</sup> L mol<sup>−1</sup>sec<sup>−1</sup> in seawater.<ref name="KeiberDavid" /> The dismutation of superoxide to hydrogen peroxide can also be catalyzed by the antioxidant enzyme [[superoxide dismutase]] with a rate constant on the order of 2×10<sup>9</sup> L mol<sup>−1</sup>sec<sup>−1</sup>.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1104/pp.106.082040 |title=Production and Scavenging of Reactive Oxygen Species in Chloroplasts and Their Functions |year=2006 |last1=Asada |first1=K. |journal=Plant Physiology |volume=141 |issue=2 |pages=391–6 |pmid=16760493 |pmc=1475469}}</ref> As a result of these fast acting processes, the steady state concentration of superoxide is very small. Since superoxide is also moderately reactive towards trace metals and dissolved organic matter, any remaining superoxide is thought to be removed from the water column through reactions with these species.<ref name="KeiberDavid" /><ref name="Blough" /> As a result, the presence of superoxide in surface waters has been known to result in an increase of reduced iron.<ref name="Blough" /><ref name="Moffett">{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/es00162a012 |title=Reaction kinetics of hydrogen peroxide with copper and iron in seawater |year=1987 |last1=Moffett |first1=James W. |last2=Zika |first2=Rod G. |journal=Environmental Science & Technology |volume=21 |issue=8 |pages=804–810|bibcode=1987EnST...21..804M }}</ref> This, in turn, serves to enhance the availability of iron to phytoplankton whose growth is often limited by this key nutrient. As a charged radical species, superoxide is unlikely to significantly affect an organism's cellular function since it is not able to easily diffuse through the cell membrane. Instead, its potential toxicity lies in its ability to react with extracellular surface proteins or carbohydrates to inactivate their functions.<ref name="Fridovich">{{cite journal |pmid=3010872 |year=1986 |last1=Fridovich |first1=I |title=Biological effects of the superoxide radical |volume=247 |issue=1 |pages=1–11 |journal=Archives of Biochemistry and Biophysics |doi=10.1016/0003-9861(86)90526-6}}</ref> Although its lifetime is fairly short (about 50 microseconds), superoxide has the potential to reach cell surfaces since it has a diffusion distance of about 320 nm.<ref name="Cadenas" /><ref name="Fridovich" />
===Hydrogen peroxide production===
The reduction product of superoxide is hydrogen peroxide, one of the most studied reactive oxygen species because it occurs in relatively high concentrations, is relatively stable, and is fairly easy to measure.<ref name="KeiberDavid" /> It is thought that algal [[photosynthesis]] is one of the major modes of hydrogen peroxide production, while the production of H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> by stressed organisms is a secondary source.<ref name="Palenik" /><ref name="Palenik_a" /><ref name="Wong" /> In marine systems, hydrogen peroxide (H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>) exists at concentrations of 10<sup>−8</sup>-10<sup>−9</sup> M in the photic zone,<ref name="Wong" /> but has been found in double those concentrations in parts of the Atlantic Ocean.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0967-0645(01)00026-1 |title=The distribution of hydrogen peroxide in the southern and central Atlantic ocean |year=2001 |last1=Yuan |first1=Jinchun |last2=Shiller |first2=Alan M |journal=Deep-Sea Research Part II: Topical Studies in Oceanography |volume=48 |issue=13 |pages=2947–2970|bibcode=2001DSRII..48.2947Y }}</ref> Its lifetime, ranging from hours to days in coastal waters, can be as long as 15 days in Antarctic seawater.<ref name="KeiberDavid" /><ref name="Blough" /> H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> is important in aquatic environments because it can oxidize dissolved organic matter and affect the redox chemistry of iron, copper, and manganese.<ref name="Moffett" /> Since hydrogen peroxide, as an uncharged molecule, diffuses easily across biological membranes it can directly damage cellular constituents (DNA and enzymes) by reacting with them and deactivating their functions.<ref name="Fridovich_a" /> In addition, hydrogen peroxide reduces to the hydroxyl radical, the most reactive radical and the one with the greatest possibility for damage.<ref name="Cadenas" /><ref name="Fridovich_a" /><ref name="KeiberDavid" /><ref name="Blough" />
===Hydroxyl radical production===
Even though the superoxide and the hydrogen peroxide radicals are toxic in their own right, they become potentially more toxic when they interact to form the hydroxyl radical (OH•). This proceeds through the iron and copper catalyzed [[Haber–Weiss reaction]]:<ref>{{cite book |last=Klebanoff |first=S.J. |editor=Furth, Ralph van |title=Mononuclear phagocytes: functional aspects |year=1980 |publisher=Martinus Nijhoff |location=Boston |pages=1105–1141 |isbn=9789024722112}}</ref> O<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup> + Fe<sup>3+</sup> ↔ O<sub>2</sub> + Fe<sup>2+</sup> H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> + Fe<sup>2+</sup> ↔ Fe<sup>3+</sup> + OH• + OH<sup>−</sup>
Since iron and copper are present in coastal waters, the hydroxyl radical could be formed by reactions with either of the,<ref name="Halliwell">{{cite book |last1=Halliwell |first1=Barry |last2=Gutteridge |first2=John M. C. |title=Free Radical Biology and Medicine |year=1999 |publisher=Clarendon Press |location=Oxford |isbn=9780198500452 |edition=3rd}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1271/bbb.59.2044 |title=Catalase- and Superoxide Dismutase-induced Morphological Changes and Growth Inhibition in the Red Tide Phytoplankton ''Chattonella marina'' |year=1995 |last1=Oda |first1=Tatsuya |last2=Moritomi |first2=Junko |last3=Kawano |first3=Ienobu |last4=Hamaguchi |first4=Shiho |last5=Ishimatsu |first5=Atsushi |last6=Muramatsu |first6=Tsuyosi |journal=Bioscience, Biotechnology, and Biochemistry |volume=59 |issue=11 |pages=2044–48}}</ref> and, in fact, their oxidation does result in significant sources of hydroxyl radicals in the ocean.<ref name="Moffett" /> The hydroxyl radical is the most unstable of the ROS (lifetime of 10<sup>−7</sup>seconds), reacting with many inorganic and organic species in the surrounding environment at rates near the diffusion limit (rate constants of 10<sup>8</sup> -10<sup>10</sup> L mol<sup>−1</sup> sec<sup>−1</sup>).<ref name="Simpson">{{cite journal |pmid=3178771 |year=1988 |last1=Simpson |first1=JA |last2=Cheeseman |first2=KH |last3=Smith |first3=SE |last4=Dean |first4=RT |title=Free-radical generation by copper ions and hydrogen peroxide. Stimulation by Hepes buffer |volume=254 |issue=2 |pages=519–23 |pmc=1135108 |journal=The Biochemical Journal |doi=10.1042/bj2540519}}</ref> In seawater, the radical is removed as a result of reactions with bromide ions, while in fresh water it reacts principally with bicarbonate and carbonate ions.<ref name="KeiberDavid" /><ref name="Blough" /> Because it has such a high reactivity, day time concentrations in surface waters of the hydroxyl radical are generally very low (10<sup>−19</sup> to 10<sup>−17</sup> M).<ref name="KeiberDavid" /> The hydroxyl radical can oxidize membrane lipids and cause nucleic acids and proteins to denature. However, because the radical is so reactive, there is likely not enough time for transport to the cell surface (mean diffusion distance of 4.5 nm).<ref name="Simpson" /> Thus, direct effects to organisms of externally generated hydroxyl radicals are expected to be minimal. Indirectly, the hydroxyl radical can result in significant biogeochemical changes in marine systems by influencing the cycling of dissolved organic matter and trace metal speciation. Both intracellular and extracellular reactive oxygen species can be removed from the environment by antioxidants produced biologically as a defense mechanism. Many phytoplankton, for instance, have been found to have numerous superoxide-scavenging (superoxide dismutase) and hydrogen peroxide-scavenging enzymes (catalase, ascorbate peroxidase, and glutathione peroxidase).<ref>{{cite book |last=K. |first=Asada |author2=Baker, N.R. |author3=Boyer, J.B. |year=1994 |chapter=Mechanisms for scavenging reactive molecules generated in chloroplasts under light stress |title=Photoinhibition of photosynthesis: from molecular mechanisms to the field |publisher=Bios Scientific Publishers |location=Oxford, UK |pages=129–142 |isbn=9781872748030}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/09670269600651471 |title=Production, scavenging and toxicity of hydrogen peroxide in the green seaweed ''Ulva rigida'' |year=1996 |last1=Collén |first1=Jonas |last2=Pedersén |first2=Marianne |journal=European Journal of Phycology |volume=31 |issue=3 |pages=265–271}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=14622986 |year=2003 |last1=Barros |first1=MP |last2=Granbom |first2=M |last3=Colepicolo |first3=P |last4=Pedersén |first4=M |title=Temporal mismatch between induction of superoxide dismutase and ascorbate peroxidase correlates with high H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> concentration in seawater from clofibrate-treated red algae ''Kappaphycus alvarezii'' |volume=420 |issue=1 |pages=161–8 |journal=Archives of Biochemistry and Biophysics |doi=10.1016/j.abb.2003.09.014}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0022-0981(03)00042-X |title=Responses of marine macroalgae to hydrogen-peroxide stress |year=2003 |last1=Dummermuth |first1=A.L |last2=Karsten |first2=U |last3=Fisch |first3=K.M |last4=König |first4=G.M |last5=Wiencke |first5=C |journal=Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology |volume=289 |pages=103–121}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.jembe.2003.08.007 |title=Oxidative stress tolerance in the filamentous green algae Cladophora glomerata and Enteromorpha ahlneriana |year=2004 |last1=Choo |first1=Kyung-sil |last2=Snoeijs |first2=Pauli |last3=Pedersén |first3=Marianne |journal=Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology |volume=298 |pages=111–123}}</ref> The antioxidant superoxide dismutase catalyses the formation of hydrogen peroxide from the superoxide anion through the following reaction:<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=3315461 |year=1987 |last1=Bannister |first1=JV |last2=Bannister |first2=WH |last3=Rotilio |first3=G |title=Aspects of the structure, function, and applications of superoxide dismutase |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=111–80 |journal=Critical Reviews in Biochemistry |doi=10.3109/10409238709083738}}</ref> 2 O<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup> + 2H<sup>+</sup> ↔ O<sub>2</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>. Similarly, catalase increases the formation of water from hydrogen peroxide by catalyzing the reaction:<ref>{{cite book |editor-last=Gilbert |editor-first=Daniel L. |title=Oxygen and living processes: An interdisciplinary approach |year=1981 |publisher=Springer-Verlag |location=New York |last1=Forman |first1=H. |last2=Fisher |first2=A.B. |chapter=Antioxidant defense |isbn=978-0387905549 }}</ref> 2H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>↔ O<sub>2</sub> + 2H<sub>2</sub>O. As a result of this reaction, the hydroxyl radical is prevented from forming. In addition, the presence of large quantities of humics in the water can also act as antioxidants of ROS.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0304-4203(99)00101-2 |title=Photogeneration of singlet oxygen and free radicals in dissolved organic matter isolated from the Mississippi and Atchafalaya River plumes |year=2000 |last1=Sandvik |first1=Sonya L.Holder |last2=Bilski |first2=Piotr |last3=Pakulski |first3=J.Dean |last4=Chignell |first4=Colin F. |last5=Coffin |first5=Richard B. |journal=Marine Chemistry |volume=69 |pages=139–152}}</ref> However, it must be noted that certain ROS can inactivate certain enzymes. For instance, the superoxide anion is known to temporarily inhibit the function of catalase at high concentrations.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Singleton |first1=Paul |last2=Sainsbury |first2=Diana |title=Dictionary or microbiology and molecular biology |edition=3rd |publisher=Wiley |location=Chichester, UK |year=2001 |page=751 |isbn=978-0-470-03545-0}}</ref>
==Controls of ROS production in algae==
Many algal species have been shown to not only produce reactive oxygen species under normal conditions but to increase production of these compounds under stressful situations. In particular, ROS levels have been shown to be influenced by cell size, cell density, growth stage, light intensity, temperature, and nutrient availability.
===Cell size===
Oda ''et al.''<ref name="Oda" /> found that differences in the production of ROS were due to the size of the cell. By comparing four species of flagellates, they showed that the larger species Ichatonella produced the most superoxide and hydrogen peroxide per cell than ''[[Heterosigma akashiwo]]'', ''Olisthodiscus luteus'', and ''Fibrocapsa japonica''. In a comparison of 37 species of marine microalgae, including dinoflagellates, rhaphidophytes, and chlorophytes, Marshall ''et al.''<ref name="Marshall_a" /> also found a direct relationship between cell size and the amount of superoxide produced. The largest cells, ''Chattonella marina'', produced up to 100 times more superoxide than most other marine algae (see figure in <ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.3354/meps09036 |title=Ichthyotoxicity of gymnodinioid dinoflagellates: PUFA and superoxide effects in sheepshead minnow larvae and rainbow trout gill cells |year=2011 |last1=Mooney |first1=BD |last2=Dorantes-Aranda |first2=JJ |last3=Place |first3=AR |last4=Hallegraeff |first4=GM |journal=Marine Ecology Progress Series |volume=426 |pages=213–224|bibcode=2011MEPS..426..213M }}</ref>). The authors suggest that since ROS is produced as a byproduct of metabolism, and larger cells are more metabolically active than smaller cells, it follows that larger cells should produce more ROS. Similarly, since photosynthesis also produces ROS, larger cells likely have a greater volume of chloroplasts and would be expected to produce more ROS than smaller cells.
===Algal density===
The production of ROS has also been shown to be dependent on algal cell density. Marshall ''et al.''<ref name="Marshall_a" /> found that for ''Chattonella marina'', higher concentrations of cells produced less superoxide per cell than those with a lower density. This may explain why some raphydophyte blooms are toxic at low concentration and non-toxic in heavy blooms.<ref name="Twiner">{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/plankt/22.10.1961 |title=Possible physiological mechanisms for production of hydrogen peroxide by the ichthyotoxic flagellate ''Heterosigma akashiwo'' |year=2000 |last1=Twiner |first1=M. J. |journal=Journal of Plankton Research |volume=22 |issue=10 |pages=1961–75}}</ref> Tang & Gobler<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.hal.2008.10.001 |title=Characterization of the toxicity of ''Cochlodinium polykrikoides'' isolates from Northeast US estuaries to finfish and shellfish |year=2009 |last1=Tang |first1=Ying Zhong |last2=Gobler |first2=Christopher J. |journal=Harmful Algae |volume=8 |issue=3 |pages=454–62}}</ref> also found that cell density was inversely related to ROS production for the alga Cochlodinium polykrikoides. They found, in addition, that increases of ROS production were also related to the growth phase of algae. In particular, algae in exponential growth were more toxic than those in the stationary or late exponential phase. Many other algal species (''[[Heterosigma akashiwo]]'', ''Chattonella marina'', and ''Chattonella antiqua'') have also been shown to produce the highest amounts of ROS during the exponential phase of growth.<ref name="Twiner" /><ref name="PortuneKevin">{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1529-8817.2010.00906.x |title=Antioxidant Enzyme Response and Reactive Oxygen Species Production in Marine Raphidophytes1 |year=2010 |last1=Portune |first1=Kevin J. |last2=Craig Cary |first2=Stephen |last3=Warner |first3=Mark E. |journal=Journal of Phycology |volume=46 |issue=6 |pages=1161–1171}}</ref> Oda ''et al.''<ref name="Oda" /> suggest this is due to actively growing cells having higher photosynthesis and metabolic rates. Resting stage cells of ''[[Chattonella antiqua]]'' have been shown to generate less superoxide than their motile counterparts.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/plankt/16.2.161 |title=Generation of superoxide anion radicals by the marine phytoplankton organism, ''Chattonella antiqua'' |year=1994 |last1=Tanaka |first1=Kazuko |last2=Muto |first2=Yoshinori |last3=Shimada |first3=Masahisa |journal=Journal of Plankton Research |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=161–69}}</ref>
===Light levels===
Since superoxide is produced through the auto-oxidation of an electron acceptor in photosystem I during photosynthesis, one would expect a positive relationship between light levels and algal ROS production.<ref name="Marshall_a" /> This is indeed what has been shown: in the diatom ''[[Thallasia weissflogii]]'', an increase in light intensity caused an increase in the production of both superoxide and hydrogen peroxide.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.4319/lom.2009.7.706 |title=Real-time detection of reactive oxygen species generation by marine phytoplankton using flow injection—chemiluminescence |year=2009 |last1=Milne |first1=Angela |last2=Davey |first2=Margaret S. |last3=Worsfold |first3=Paul J. |last4=Achterberg |first4=Eric P. |last5=Taylor |first5=Alison R. |journal=Limnology and Oceanography: Methods |volume=7 |pages=706–15}}</ref> Similarly, in the flagellates ''[[Chattonella marina]]'', ''Prorocentrum minimum'', and ''Cochlodinium polykrikoides'', decreases in light levels resulted in decreases in superoxide production,<ref name="Marshall_a" /><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s002270100614 |title=Possible involvement of the glycocalyx in the ichthyotoxicity of ''Chattonella marina'' (Raphidophyceae): Immunological approach using antiserum against cell surface structures of the flagellate |year=2001 |last1=d(-k.). |first1=Kim |last2=t. |first2=Okamoto |last3=t. |first3=Oda |last4=k. |first4=Tachibana |last5=k.s. |first5=Lee |last6=a. |first6=Ishimatsu |last7=y. |first7=Matsuyama |last8=t. |first8=Honjo |last9=t. |first9=Muramatsu |journal=Marine Biology |volume=139 |issue=4 |pages=625–632 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s12601-009-0018-z |title=Physiological and biochemical responses of Prorocentrum minimum to high light stress |year=2010 |last1=Park |first1=So Yun |last2=Choi |first2=Eun Seok |last3=Hwang |first3=Jinik |last4=Kim |first4=Donggiun |last5=Ryu |first5=Tae Kwon |last6=Lee |first6=Taek-Kyun |journal=Ocean Science Journal |volume=44 |issue=4 |pages=199–204|bibcode=2009OSJ....44..199P }}</ref> with higher levels produced during the day. However, because many studies have found ROS production to be relatively high even in the dark, metabolic pathways other than photosynthesis are likely more important for production.<ref name="PortuneKevin" /> For instance, Liu ''et al.''<ref name="Liu">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.jembe.2007.03.007 |title=Effects of nutrients, salinity, pH and light:dark cycle on the production of reactive oxygen species in the alga ''Chattonella marina'' |year=2007 |last1=Liu |first1=Wenhua |last2=Au |first2=Doris W.T. |last3=Anderson |first3=Donald M. |last4=Lam |first4=Paul K.S. |last5=Wu |first5=Rudolf S.S. |journal=Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology |volume=346 |pages=76–86|url=http://darchive.mblwhoilibrary.org/bitstream/1912/1764/1/algal%20ROS%20production%20JEMBE%20revised%206_3_07.pdf }}</ref> found that ROS production was regulated by iron concentration and pH. From this evidence they suggest that ROS production is most likely due to a plasma membrane enzyme system dependent on iron availability. Similarly, in Heterosigma akashiwo, the depletion of iron and an increase in temperature, not light intensity, resulted in enhanced production of ROS.<ref name="Twiner" /> Liu ''et al.''<ref name="Liu" /> found the same relationship with temperature.
==Functions of algal produced ROS==
The active release of reactive oxygen species from cells has a variety of purposes, including a means to deter predators, or a chemical defense for the incapacitation of competitors.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S1568-9883(02)00048-3 |title=The toxigenic marine dinoflagellate Alexandrium tamarense as the probable cause of mortality of caged salmon in Nova Scotia |year=2002 |last1=Cembella |first1=A.D |last2=Quilliam |first2=M.A |last3=Lewis |first3=N.I |last4=Bauder |first4=A.G |last5=Dell'Aversano |first5=C |last6=Thomas |first6=K |last7=Jellett |first7=J |last8=Cusack |first8=R.R |journal=Harmful Algae |volume=1 |issue=3 |pages=313–325}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2216/i0031-8884-42-4-406.1 |title=Allelopathy in phytoplankton - biochemical, ecological and evolutionary aspects |year=2003 |last1=Legrand |first1=Catherine |last2=Rengefors |first2=Karin |last3=Fistarol |first3=Giovana O. |last4=Granéli |first4=Edna |journal=Phycologia |volume=42 |issue=4 |pages=406–419}}</ref><ref name="Graneli">{{cite book |last1=Granéli |first1=E. |last2=Hansen |first2=P. J. |date=2006 |chapter=Allelopathy in Harmful Algae: A Mechanism to Compete for Resources? |title=Ecology of Harmful Algae |volume=189 |series=Ecological Studies |publisher=Springer |pages=189–206 |doi=10.1007/978-3-540-32210-8_15 |isbn=978-3-540-32209-2 }}</ref> In addition, ROS may be involved in cell signaling, as well as the oxidation or reduction of necessary or toxic metals.<ref name="Palenik" /><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/plankt/fbm034 |title=On the allelochemical potency of the marine dinoflagellate Alexandrium ostenfeldii against heterotrophic and autotrophic protists |year=2007 |last1=Tillmann |first1=U. |last2=John |first2=U. |last3=Cembella |first3=A. |journal=Journal of Plankton Research |volume=29 |issue=6 |pages=527–543}}</ref>
===Chemical defense===
It is not surprising that ROS production may be a form of chemical defense against predators, since at low levels it can damage DNA and at high levels lead to cell necrosis.<ref name="Lesser" /> One of the most common mechanisms of cellular injury is the reaction of ROS with lipids, which can disrupt enzyme activity and ATP production, and lead to apoptosis.<ref name="Halliwell" /> Reactions of ROS with proteins can modify amino acids, fragment peptide chains, alter electrical charges, and ultimately inactivate an enzyme's function.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0968-0004(86)90221-5 |title=Oxidation of proteins by mixed-function oxidation systems: Implication in protein turnover, ageing and neutrophil function |year=1986 |last1=Stadtman |first1=E.R. |journal=Trends in Biochemical Sciences |volume=11 |pages=11–12}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=3036875 |year=1987 |last1=Davies |first1=KJ |title=Protein damage and degradation by oxygen radicals. I. General aspects |volume=262 |issue=20 |pages=9895–901 |journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry}}</ref> In DNA, deletions, mutations, and other lethal genetic effects may result from reactions with ROS.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=3287616 |year=1988 |last1=Imlay |first1=JA |last2=Linn |first2=S |title=DNA damage and oxygen radical toxicity |volume=240 |issue=4857 |pages=1302–9 |journal=Science |doi=10.1126/science.3287616|bibcode=1988Sci...240.1302I }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=14527285 |year=2003 |last1=Imlay |first1=JA |title=Pathways of oxidative damage |volume=57 |pages=395–418 |doi=10.1146/annurev.micro.57.030502.090938 |journal=Annual Review of Microbiology}}</ref> Reactive oxygen species are especially inexpensive to produce as defense chemicals, simply because they are not composed of metabolically costly elements such as carbon, nitrogen, or phosphate. Reactive oxygen species produced by phytoplankton have been linked to deaths of fish, shellfish, and protists, as well as shown to reduce the viability and growth of bacteria.<ref name="IshimatsuAtsushi" /><ref name="Twiner" /><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=24176 |year=1978 |last1=Babior |first1=BM |title=Oxygen-dependent microbial killing by phagocytes (first of two parts) |volume=298 |issue=12 |pages=659–68 |doi=10.1056/NEJM197803232981205 |journal=The New England Journal of Medicine}}</ref><ref name="KimDaekyung">{{cite journal |last1=Kim |first1=Daekyung |last2=Nakamura |first2=Atsushi |last3=Okamoto |first3=Tarou |last4=Komatsu |first4=Nobukazu |last5=Oda |first5=Tatsuya |last6=Ishimatsu |first6=Atsushi |last7=Muramatsu |first7=Tsuyoshi |journal=Journal of Plankton Research |title=Toxic potential of the raphidophyte Olisthodiscus luteus: mediation by reactive oxygen species |volume=21 |issue=6 |pages=1017–27 |year=1999 |issn=0142-7873 |doi=10.1093/plankt/21.6.1017}}</ref> In addition, a study by Marshall ''et al.''<ref name="Marshall_a" /> showed that four algal species used as bivalve feed produced significantly lower concentrations of superoxide, suggesting that ROS production by other algal species may be a way to decrease grazing by bivalves. The most direct evidence for ROS as a defense mechanism is the fact that many icthyotoxic algae produce greater concentrations of ROS than nonichthyotoxic strains.<ref name="Oda" /><ref name="Marshall_a" /><ref name="Yang" /><ref name="Twiner" />
===Enhancement of toxic exudates===
It is possible that ROS may not be the actual toxic substance, but may in fact work to make other exudates more toxic by oxidizing them.<ref name="Marshall_a" /><ref name="Okaichi">{{cite book |last1=Okaichi |first1=Tomotoshi |last2=Mark Anderson |first2=Donald |last3=Nemoto |first3=Takahisa |title=Red tides: biology, environmental science, and toxicology |year=1989 |publisher=Elsevier |location=New York |isbn=9780444013439 |pages=145–176 |chapter=Proceedings of the first international symposium on Red tides}}</ref> For instance, ROS from ''Chattonella marina'' have been shown to enhance the toxic effects of fatty acid eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) on exposed fishes.<ref name="Marshall_a" /><ref name="Okaichi" /> Similarly, free-fatty acids released from diatom biofilms as products of ROS oxidation of EPA are known to be toxic to zooplankters.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1046/j.1529-8817.2001.00130.x |title=Liberation of 5,8,11,14,17-Eicosapentaenoic Acid and Other Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids from Lipids As a Grazer Defense Reaction in Epilithic Diatom Biofilms |year=2001 |last1=Juttner |first1=Friedrich |journal=Journal of Phycology |volume=37 |issue=5 |pages=744–55}}</ref> In addition, Fontana ''et al.''<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=17886321 |year=2007 |last1=Fontana |first1=A |last2=d'Ippolito |first2=G |last3=Cutignano |first3=A |last4=Romano |first4=G |last5=Lamari |first5=N |last6=Massa Gallucci |first6=A |last7=Cimino |first7=G |last8=Miralto |first8=A |last9=Ianora |first9=A |title=LOX-induced lipid peroxidation mechanism responsible for the detrimental effect of marine diatoms on zooplankton grazers |volume=8 |issue=15 |pages=1810–8 |doi=10.1002/cbic.200700269 |journal=ChemBioChem}}</ref> suggested that the interaction of ROS and diatom exudates (such as fatty acid hydroperoxides) are responsible for inhibiting embryonic development and causing larval abnormalities in copepods. Finally, ROS oxidation of algal polyunsaturated fatty acids have also been shown to deter grazers.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Ikawa |first=M. |title=Algal polyunsaturated fatty acids and effects on plankton ecology and other organisms |url=http://www.cfb.unh.edu/PDF/2004/UNHCFBR-6-2-2004.pdf |journal=UNH Center for Freshwater Biology Research |volume=6 |issue=2 |year=2004 |pages=17–44}}</ref>
===Competitive advantage===
In addition to impacting predator-prey interactions, the production of ROS may also help an alga get an advantage in the competition for resources against other algae, be a way to prevent fouling bacteria, and act as a signaling mechanism between cells.<ref name="Graneli" /><ref name="KimDaekyung" /><ref name="Oda_a">{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/BF00356297 |title=Oxygen-radical-mediated toxic effects of the red tide flagellate Chattonella marina on Vibrio alginolyticus |year=1992 |last1=Oda |first1=T. |last2=Ishimatsu |first2=A. |last3=Shimada |first3=M. |last4=Takeshita |first4=S. |last5=Muramatsu |first5=T. |journal=Marine Biology |volume=112 |issue=3 |pages=505–9}}</ref> ROS can inhibit photosynthesis in algae<ref name="Lesser" /> Thus an alga that is more tolerant of ROS than another may produce and release it as a means of decreasing the other species competitive ability. In addition, ''Chattonella marina'', the most well studied raphydophyte for ROS production, may produce a boundary of ROS that deters other marine microalgae from using nutrients in its vicinity.<ref name="Marshall" /> Similarly, this boundary could also be a way to discourage bacteria fouling, since the production of ROS is known to inhibit growth and bioluminescent ability in the bacteria ''[[Vibrio alginolyticus]]'' and ''[[Vibrio fischeri]]'', respectively.<ref name="KimDaekyung" /><ref name="Oda_a" /> Lastly, Marshall ''et al.''<ref name="Marshall" /> showed that ''Chattonella marina'' cells were able to change their rate of superoxide production in as little as one hour when in different cell densities, increasing the rate from 1.4 to 7.8 times the original. They suggest that this quick response in altering rates of production may be a form of chemical signaling between cells that works to provide information about cell density.
===Reduction of metals===
ROS may be useful in the oxidation or reduction of necessary or toxic metals. Since iron is necessary for phytoplankton growth, the auto-reduction of reactive oxygen species may be a way for algae to get usable iron from free or organically bound ferric iron.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0304-4203(95)00035-p |title=Iron uptake and growth limitation in oceanic and coastal phytoplankton |year=1995 |last1=Sunda |first1=William G. |last2=Huntsman |first2=Susan A. |journal=Marine Chemistry |volume=50 |pages=189–206}}</ref> For instance, Cakman ''et al.''<ref name="Cakman">{{cite journal |pmid=16665677 |year=1987 |last1=Cakmak |first1=I |last2=Van De Wetering |first2=DA |last3=Marschner |first3=H |last4=Bienfait |first4=HF |title=Involvement of superoxide radical in extracellular ferric reduction by iron-deficient bean roots |volume=85 |issue=1 |pages=310–4 |pmc=1054247 |journal=Plant Physiology |doi=10.1104/pp.85.1.310}}</ref> showed that ROS may increase the amount of iron available through extracellular ferric reduction. It is thought that the high reducing power of this reaction is maintained through the electron-rich superoxide ion.<ref name="Cakman" /> In several studies on the ROS production of ''Heterosigma akashiwo'', hydrogen peroxide production was found to be inversely proportional to the concentration of iron available.<ref name="Twiner" /><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.4319/lo.2001.46.6.1400 |title=Toxic effects of Heterosigma akashiwo do not appear to be mediated by hydrogen peroxide |year=2001 |last1=Twiner |first1=Michael J. |last2=Dixon |first2=S. Jeffrey |last3=Trick |first3=Charles G. |journal=Limnology and Oceanography |volume=46 |issue=6 |pages=1400–05|bibcode=2001LimOc..46.1400T }}</ref> In addition, Cornish and Page in 1998 found that phytoplankton produce more ROS when there are lower levels of extracellular iron. They suggested that when intracellular iron is limiting, the phytoplankton respond by producing more ROS as a way to increase the reducing potential around the cell and thus be better able to reduce that iron to a usable form. Similarly, lower ROS production would suggest that the intracellular iron is at sufficiently high levels for cellular function.

[[Image:Wind power plants in Xinjiang, China.jpg|thumb| [[Wind farm]] in [[Xinjiang]], China]] [[File:Solar-Panel-Cooker-in-front-of-hut.jpg|thumb| [[Solar cooker]]s use sunlight as energy source for outdoor cooking.]]
Renewable energy technology has sometimes been seen as a costly luxury item by critics, and affordable only in the affluent developed world. This erroneous view has persisted for many years, but 2015 was the first year when investment in non-hydro renewables, was higher in developing countries, with $156 billion invested, mainly in China, India, and Brazil.<ref>FS-UNEP Collaborating Centre, [http://fs-unep-centre.org/sites/default/files/publications/globaltrendsinrenewableenergyinvestment2016lowres_0.pdf Global trends in renewable energy investment], 2016 p. 14.</ref>
Most developing countries have abundant [[renewable energy]] resources, including [[solar energy]], [[wind power]], [[geothermal energy]], and [[biomass]], as well as the ability to manufacture the relatively labor-intensive systems that harness these. By developing such energy sources developing countries can reduce their dependence on oil and natural gas, creating energy portfolios that are less vulnerable to price rises. In many circumstances, these investments can be less expensive than fossil fuel energy systems.<ref name=mdg>[http://www.worldwatch.org/system/files/ren21-1.pdf Energy for Development: The Potential Role of Renewable Energy in Meeting the Millennium Development Goals] pp. 7-9.</ref>
In isolated rural areas, [[electricity grid]] extensions are often not economical. Off‐grid renewable technologies provide a sustainable and cost‐effective alternative to the [[diesel generator]]s that would be otherwise be deployed in such areas. Renewable technologies can also help to displace other unsustainable energy sources such as [[kerosene lamp]]s and [[biomass|traditional biomass]].<ref name=reeee/>
[[Kenya]] is the world leader in the number of [[solar power]] systems installed per capita (but not the number of watts added). More than 30,000 small [[solar panel]]s, each producing 12 to 30 watts, are sold in Kenya annually. Kenya was the first African country to use [[geothermal power in Kenya|geothermal power]], and still has the largest installed capacity of geothermal power in Africa at 200 MW, with a potential of up to 10 GW.<ref name="en.ccchina.gov.cn">http://en.ccchina.gov.cn/Detail.aspx?newsId=38323&TId=97</ref>
==Rationale for renewable energy== In 2009, about 1.4 billion of people in the world lived without electricity, and 2.7 billion relied on wood, charcoal, and dung for home energy requirements. This lack of access to modern energy technology limits income generation, blunts efforts to escape poverty, affects people's health, and contributes to global deforestation and climate change. Small-scale renewable energy technologies and [[distributed energy]] options, such as onsite solar power and improved cookstoves, offer rural households modern energy services.<ref name=verlaw>{{cite web |ssrn=2198045 |title=Deploying Off-Grid Technology to Eradicate Energy Poverty |author=Sovacool, Benjamin K., |date=5 October 2012 |work=Science (vol. 338, 47-48)}}</ref>
Renewable energy can be particularly suitable for developing countries. In rural and remote areas, transmission and distribution of energy generated from [[fossil fuels]] can be difficult and expensive. Producing renewable energy locally can offer a viable alternative.<ref name=aus>[http://www.ausaid.gov.au/publications/pdf/renewable_energy.pdf Power for the People] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120330120425/http://www.ausaid.gov.au/publications/pdf/renewable_energy.pdf |date=2012-03-30 }} p. 3.</ref>
Renewable energy doesn't always have to come from a developing country. The Developing Areas Study Group session is a group of speakers from all over the energy businesses discusses the potential ideas to get developing countries the renewable energy that they need. Papers written by W. Morgan, R. Moss and P. Richard discuss the opportunities of renewable resources that lie within the developing country as well. Morgan and Richard claim firewood and agriculture could play a great role in an alternative energy solution in developing countries, while Richards claims that efficient use of agriculture could lead to renewable energy. Morgan also points out that green plants could play a great role in producing synthetic fuel alcohol, which would not only impact the developing country but the world as a whole in providing an alternative fuel source.<ref>{{Cite journal |jstor= 20001554 |title= Energy in Developing Countries |last= McDonald |first= Paul |date= 1980 |journal= Area |accessdate= |doi= |pmid= }}</ref>
Interest in renewable energies has increased in recent years due to environmental concern about [[global warming]] and [[air pollution]], reduced costs of the technologies themselves, and improved efficiency and reliability.<ref name=aus/> In recent years, supportive programs from governments, businesses, nonprofit organizations, and community cooperatives have expanded access to these off-grid technologies and the energy services they provide. Program planners should select “low-hanging fruit” first, aiming for maximum access to modern energy services with the least effort.<ref name=verlaw/>
==Use of renewables== Collectively, developing countries have more than half of global renewable power capacity. China and India are rapidly expanding markets for renewable energy. Brazil produces most of the world’s sugar-derived ethanol and has been adding new biomass and wind power plants. Many renewable markets are growing at rapid rates in countries such as Argentina, Costa Rica, Egypt, Indonesia, Kenya, Tanzania, Thailand, Tunisia, and Uruguay.<ref name=ren9>[[REN21]] (2010). [http://www.ren21.net/globalstatusreport/REN21_GSR_2010_full.pdf Renewables 2010 Global Status Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820221548/http://www.ren21.net/globalstatusreport/REN21_GSR_2010_full.pdf |date=2010-08-20 }} p. 9.</ref>
In isolated rural areas, electricity grid extensions are often not economical. Off‐grid renewable technologies provide a sustainable and cost‐effective alternative to the diesel generators that would be otherwise be deployed in such areas. Renewable technologies can also help to displace other unsustainable energy sources such as kerosene lamps and traditional biomass.<ref name="reeee">{{cite web |url=http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/Renew_Policies.pdf |title=Renewable Energy |author=IEA |year=2011 |work= }}</ref>
Technology advances are opening up a huge new market for solar power: the approximately 1.3 billion people around the world who don't have access to grid electricity. Even though they are typically very poor, these people have to pay far more for lighting than people in rich countries because they use inefficient kerosene lamps. Solar power costs half as much as lighting with kerosene.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.technologyreview.com/energy/39544/?p1=MstCom |title=In the Developing World, Solar is Cheaper than Fossil Fuels |author= Kevin Bullis |date= January 27, 2012 |work= Technology Review }}</ref> An estimated 3 million households get power from small solar PV systems.<ref name=re10>REN21 (2010). [http://www.ren21.net/globalstatusreport/REN21_GSR_2010_full.pdf Renewables 2010 Global Status Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820221548/http://www.ren21.net/globalstatusreport/REN21_GSR_2010_full.pdf |date=2010-08-20 }} p. 12.</ref> Kenya is the world leader in the number of solar power systems installed per capita. More than 30,000 very small solar panels, each producing 12 to 30 watts, are sold in Kenya annually.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rael.berkeley.edu/files/2006/Kammen-SciAm-Renewables-9-06.pdf |title=The Rise of Renewable Energy |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-11-21}}</ref>
Micro-hydro systems configured into village-scale or county-scale mini-grids serve many areas. More than 30 million rural households get lighting and cooking from biogas made in household-scale systems. These stoves are being manufactured in factories and workshops worldwide, and more than 160 million households now use them.<ref name = re10/>
===Poverty alleviation=== {{See also|Energy poverty}} Renewable energy projects in many developing countries have demonstrated that renewable energy can directly contribute to [[poverty alleviation]] by providing the energy needed for creating businesses and employment. Renewable energy technologies can also make indirect contributions to alleviating poverty by providing energy for cooking, space heating, and lighting.<ref name=mdg/>
===Education=== Renewable energy can also contribute to education, by providing electricity to schools. Renewable energy for cooking and heating can reduce the time that children spend out of school collecting fuel.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ashdenawards.org/winners/grameen08 |title=Grameen Shakti installs efficient stoves as well as solar home systems |author=Ashden Awards |accessdate=2008-11-25}}</ref>
===Health=== 2.4 billion people use only traditional biomass, such as wood, residues and dung, for cooking and heating. The constant use of these types of energy sources exposes them to indoor particulate and carbon monoxide concentrations many times higher than [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) standards. "Traditional stoves using dung and charcoal emit large amounts of carbon monoxide and other noxious gases. Women and children suffer most, because they are exposed for the longest periods of time. Acute respiratory illnesses affect as much as 6% of the world population. The WHO estimates that 2.5 million women and young children in developing countries die prematurely each year from breathing the fumes from indoor biomass stoves".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iaea.org/Publications/Magazines/Bulletin/Bull442/44204002429.pdf|title=IAEA BULLETIN, 44/2/2002|pages=28, 29}}</ref> Renewable energy can improve this situation by reducing exposure to indoor pollutants.
Furthermore, renewable can also provide energy to refrigerate medicine and sterilize medical equipment in rural areas where the access to electricity is difficult.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ashdenawards.org/winners/kxn |title=PV-powered vaccine fridges |author=Ashden Awards |accessdate=2008-11-25}}</ref> It can also provide power to supply the fresh water and sewerage services needed to reduce the spread of infectious diseases.<ref name=mdg/>
==Government policies== {{Further|Renewable energy policy}} More developing countries are implementing the public policies needed for the widespread development of renewable energy technologies and markets, which have traditionally been dominated by Europe, Japan, and North America. The exceptions include countries like Brazil, which has built the world’s leading [[biofuel]]s industry, [[Renewable energy in China|China]], India, which are leaders in developing decentralized renewable sources such as [[small hydro]], small wind, biogas, and solar water heating.<ref name=mdg/> However, policies like [[feed-in tariff]] are applied. Besides, with the [[Kyoto Protocol]], the program called the [[Clean Development Mechanism]] (CDM) that allows for industrialized nations to invest in projects that reduce emissions in developing countries as an alternative to more expensive emission reductions in their own countries.<ref>[http://unfccc.int/cooperation_and_support/financial_mechanism/adaptation_fund/items/3659.php Adaptation Fund]</ref>
Developing-country Governments need to steer resources mobilized for large-scale investments into new production sectors and new technologies. Some argue that policies should base on active industrial policies, combining large scale investments and active policy interventions. There is a need of subsidizing these type of energy services to make them affordable to the major part of the population.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.un.org/esa/desa/desalert/2009/WESS_overview_en.pdf|title=World Economic and Social Survey 2009 Promoting Development, Saving, 2009, the Planet|pages=4, 11}}</ref>
===Asia===
==== China ==== {{Main|Renewable energy in China}}
==== India ==== {{Main|Renewable energy in India}}
==== Pakistan ==== {{Main|Renewable energy in Pakistan}}
==== Philippines ==== {{main|Renewable Energy in the Philippines}} [[File:Bangui Wind Mills.JPG|thumb|[[Bangui Wind Farm]] in [[Ilocos Norte]], [[Philippines]]]] The [[Philippines|Philippine]] government sees the growth of the renewable energy sector essential for national energy security. The Philippines' fossil fuel sector is unsustainable, being dependent on the import of nonrenewable fuel, including petroleum, but has significant potential in the renewable energy sector. Based on a report of an Australian consulting firm, International Energy Consultants, the Philippines has the highest electricity rate in Asia, followed by [[Japan]]. Transmitting power and transporting fuel throughout the Philippine archipelago is problematic due to very high cost.<ref name=manila.b>http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/325264/the-right-mix-the-philippines-achieving-its-renewable-energy-goals</ref>
The Philippines could be considered a world leader in renewable energy, with its 30 percent of its power generation being powered by the renewable energy sector. the Philippines is the world's second largest generator of geothermal energy and was the first [[Southeast Asia]]n nation to invest in large-scale solar and wind technologies.<ref name=manila.b />
Promotion and support of renewable energy in the country was intensified with the passing of the Renewable Energy Act of 2008 which made a feed-in-tariff and a renewable portfolio standard. The Philippines aims to triple renewable energy supply by 2030.<ref name=manila.b /><ref>http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/business/06/14/11/philippines-lifts-2030-renewable-energy-target</ref>
Recently the government has concluded agreements with private developers for extensive projects in Oriental Mindoro with an eventual output of 48 MW, with plans for even larger development in the future.<ref>http://samueldalsanto.com/2012/04/14/samuel-helps-philippines-wind-power-project-get-presidential-approval/</ref>
Despite government efforts, some investors have criticized the government's lack of firmness in its feed-in-tariff policy, and the solar industry accused the government for hampering its progress in the country.<ref>http://www.cleanbiz.asia/story/policy-problems-hamper-philippine-renewables-growth</ref>
===Africa=== {{Main|Renewable energy in Africa}} <!-- Commented out: [[File:Earthlife Africa brouchure.jpeg|thumb|[[Earthlife Africa]] promotional brochure]] -->
====Algeria==== On February 3, 2011, Algeria launched the National Development Programme for new and renewable energy and energy efficiency.<ref>[http://portail.cder.dz/spip.php?article937] Adoption of the Algerian program of renewable energy and energy conservation policy</ref><ref>[http://portail.cder.dz/spip.php?rubrique44] Algerian Development Programme for new and renewable energy and energy efficiency</ref> The program, which spans the period from 2011 to 2013, aims to produce 22,000 MW of electricity from solar and wind power which 10,000 MW for export.<ref>[http://portail.cder.dz/spip.php?article1155] Algerian Development Programme for new and renewable energy and energy efficiency (List of projects)</ref>
====Kenya==== {{Main|Renewable energy in Kenya}} In [[Kenya]], the Ministry of Energy and Petroleum<ref>The Ministry of Energy http://www.energy.go.ke/?page_id=2</ref> is in charge of renewable energy policies. In March 2008, the country adopted the [[feed-in tariff]] policy. In January 2010, the policy was revised to urge private sectors to invest in electricity generation from renewable sources.<ref>http://www.energy.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2010/08/feed%20in%20tarriffs2.pdf</ref>
Kenya was the first African country to use [[geothermal power in Kenya|geothermal power]], and still has the largest installed capacity of geothermal power in Africa at 200 MW, with a potential of up to 10 GW.<ref name="en.ccchina.gov.cn"/> The only other country in Africa utilising geothermal power is [[Ethiopia]].
Kenya is the world leader in the number of solar power systems installed per capita (but not the number of watts added). More than 30,000 small solar panels, each producing 12 to 30 watts, are sold in Kenya annually. For an investment of as little as $100 for the panel and wiring, the PV system can be used to charge a car battery, which can then provide power to run a fluorescent lamp or a small television for a few hours a day. More Kenyans are turning to solar power every year rather than making connections to the country’s electric grid. This is due to the high connectivity costs and the fact that there is an abundance of solar power in Kenya.<ref>[http://rael.berkeley.edu/files/2006/Kammen-SciAm-Renewables-9-06.pdf The Rise of Renewable Energy]</ref>
===Latin America and the Caribbean===
==== Brazil ==== [[File:Cachoeira de Paulo Afonso.jpg|thumb|right|[[Paulo Afonso]] [[Hydroelectricity|Hydroelectric Powerplant]] in the State of [[Bahia]]]] {{Main|Renewable energy in Brazil}} [[Renewable energy]] accounted for more than 85.4% of the domestically produced electricity used in Brazil, according to preliminary data from the 2009 National Energy Balance, conducted by the Energy Research Corporation (EPE).<ref>[http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/articles/2009/12/brazils-wind-power-auction-spurs-more-clean-energy-development.html Renewable energy in Brazil]</ref> After the oil shocks of the 1970s, Brazil started focusing on developing alternative sources of energy, mainly [[Ethanol fuel in Brazil|sugarcane ethanol]]. Its large sugarcane farms helped. In 1985, 91% of cars produced that year ran on sugarcane ethanol. The success of [[flexible-fuel vehicle]]s, introduced in 2003, together with the mandatory E25 blend throughout the country, have allowed ethanol fuel consumption in the country to achieve a 50% market share of the gasoline-powered fleet by February 2008.<ref name="ANP07_2008">{{cite web|url=http://br.invertia.com/noticias/noticia.aspx?idNoticia=200807152306_ABR_77211977|title=ANP: consumo de álcool combustível é 50% maior em 2007|author=Agência Brasil|date=2008-07-15|publisher=Invertia|accessdate=2008-08-09|language=Portuguese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081226014527/http://br.invertia.com/noticias/noticia.aspx?idNoticia=200807152306_ABR_77211977|archivedate=2008-12-26|df=}}</ref><ref>[http://www.redebrasilatual.com.br/temas/economia/gabrielli-etanol-reduzira-mercado-de-gasolina-a-17-ate-2020 90% of cars produced in Brazil are Flexfuel]</ref>
====Costa Rica==== [[Renewable Energy in Costa Rica]] accounts for over 90% of the total output of the nation's energy. The country is the world leader in renewable use with massive investment in windmill technologies. The government aim is to make the country the world's first carbon neutral country.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lavca.org/2010/07/13/latin-american-policy-changes-investing-in-renewable-energy-climate-change-and-clean-technology/|title=Latin American Policy Changes: Investing in Renewable Energy, Climate Change and Clean Technology|author=Latin America Venture Capital Association |date= 13 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrdc.org/international/costa.pdf |title=Costa Rica: Setting the Pace for Reducing Global Warming Pollution and Phasing Out oil|author=Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) |date=June 2007}}</ref> In March 2015 the whole country was running over 75 straight days on 100% renewable energy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sciencealert.com/costa-rica-powered-with-100-renewable-energy-for-75-days|title=Costa Rica powered with 100% renewable energy for 75 straight days|date=March 2015}}</ref>
