'''Repetition priming''' refers to improvements in a behavioural response when stimuli are repeatedly presented. The improvements can be measured in terms of ''accuracy'' or ''reaction time'', and can occur when the repeated stimuli are either identical or similar to previous stimuli.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Schacter|first1=D.L|last2=Buckner|first2=R.L|title=Priming and the brain|journal=Neuron|date=1998|volume=20|pages=185–195|doi=10.1016/s0896-6273(00)80448-1}}</ref> These improvements have been shown to be cumulative, so as the number of repetitions increases the responses get continually faster up to a maximum of around seven repetitions.<ref name=Maljkovic>{{cite journal|last1=Maljkovic|first1=V|last2=Nakayama|first2=K|title=Priming of pop-out: I. Role of features|journal=Memory & Cognition|date=1994|volume=22|pages=657–672|doi=10.3758/bf03209251|pmid=7808275}}</ref> These improvements are also found when the repeated items are changed slightly in terms of orientation,<ref name="Biederman 1">{{cite journal|last1=Biederman|first1=I|last2=Cooper|first2=E.E|title=Evidence for complete translational and reflectional invariance in visual object recognition|journal=Perception|date=1991|volume=20|pages=585–593|doi=10.1068/p200585}}</ref> size<ref name="Biederman 2">{{cite journal|last1=Biederman|first1=I|last2=Cooper|first2=E.E|title=Size invariance in visual object recognition|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Human Perception and Performance|date=1992|volume=18|issue=1|pages=121–133|doi=10.1037/0096-1523.18.1.121}}</ref> and position.<ref name=Fiser>{{cite journal|last1=Fiser|first1=J|last2=Biederman|first2=I|title=Invariance of long-term visual priming to scale, reflection, translation, and hemisphere|journal=Vision Research|date=2001|volume=41|issue=2|pages=221–234|doi=10.1016/s0042-6989(00)00234-0}}</ref> The size of the effect is also modulated by the length of time the item is presented for<ref name=Huber>{{cite journal|last1=Huber|first1=D.E|last2=Clark|first2=T.F|last3=Curran|first3=T|last4=Winkielman|first4=P|title=Effects of repetition priming on recognition memory: Testing a perceptual fluency-disfluency model|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition|date=2008|volume=34|issue=6|pages=1305–1324|doi=10.1037/a0013370}}</ref> and the length time between the first and subsequent presentations of the repeated items.<ref name="Henson 1">{{cite journal|last1=Henson|first1=R.N|last2=Rylands|first2=A|last3=Ross|first3=E|last4=Vuilleumeir|first4=P|last5=Rugg|first5=M.D|title=The effect of repetition lag on electrophysiological and haemodynamic correlates of visual object priming|journal=NeuroImage|date=2004|volume=21|issue=4|pages=1674–1689|doi=10.1016/j.neuroimage.2003.12.020|pmid=15050590}}</ref>
==Description== Repetition priming can occur without a person being aware of either the repeats or the improvements in his/her response, so it is generally thought to involve [[implicit memory]] processes that are dissociable from [[explicit memory]] processes.<ref name="Rugg 1">{{cite journal|last1=Rugg|first1=M.D|last2=Mark|first2=R.E|last3=Walla|first3=P|last4=Schloerscheidt|first4=A.M|last5=Birch|first5=C.S|last6=Allan|first6=K|title=Dissociation of the neural correlates of implicit and explicit memory|journal=Nature|date=1998|volume=392|issue=6676|pages=595–598|doi=10.1038/33396}}</ref> This idea has support from findings that [[amnesic]] patients with damage to [[limbic]] and/or [[diencephalic]] structures show measurable repetition priming effects but have deficits on explicit measures of memory.<ref name="Kinder & Shanks">{{cite journal|last1=Kinder|first1=A|last2=Shanks|first2=D.R|title=Amnesia and the declarative/nondeclarative distinction: A recurrent network model of classification, recognition, and repetition priming|journal=Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience|date=2001|volume=13|issue=5|pages=648–669|doi=10.1162/089892901750363217|pmid=11506662}}</ref><ref name=Fleischman>{{cite journal|last1=Fleischman|first1=D.A|title=Repetition priming in aging and Alzheimer's disease: an integrative review and future directions|journal=Cortex|date=2007|volume=43|issue=7|pages=889–897|doi=10.1016/s0010-9452(08)70688-9}}</ref> However, some researchers suggest that implicit and explicit memory systems are not in fact separate.<ref name=Reder>{{cite journal|last1=Reder|first1=L.M|last2=Park|first2=H|last3=Kieffaber|first3=P.D|title=Memory systems do not divide on consciousness: Reinterpreting memory in terms of activation and binding|journal=Psychological Bulletin|date=2009|volume=135|issue=1|pages=23–49|doi=10.1037/a0013974}}</ref> Repetition priming has also been associated with attentional processes,<ref name=Larsson>{{cite journal|last1=Larsson|first1=J|last2=Smith|first2=A.T|title=fMRI repetition suppression: neuronal adaptation or stimulus expectation?|journal=Cerebral Cortex|date=2012|volume=22|issue=3|pages=567–576|doi=10.1093/cercor/bhr119|pmc=3278317}}</ref> stimulus expectation<ref name=Summerfield>{{cite journal|last1=Summerfield|first1=C|last2=Egner|first2=T|last3=Greene|first3=M|last4=Koechlin|first4=E|last5=Mangels|first5=J|last6=Hirsch|first6=J|title=Predictive codes for forthcoming perception in the frontal cortex|journal=Science|date=2006|volume=314|issue=5803|pages=1311–1314|doi=10.1126/science.1132028|pmid=17124325}}</ref> and [[episodic memory]].<ref name=Neill>{{cite journal|last1=Neill|first1=W.T|title=Episodic retrieval in negative priming and repetition priming|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition|date=1997|volume=23|issue=6|pages=1291–3105|doi=10.1037/0278-7393.23.6.1291}}</ref>
Research into repetition priming has been used to investigate the nature of mechanisms underlying the behavioural effects of rapid learning. In utilizing measures of ''repetition suppression'', the putative neural correlate of repetition priming, and measuring changes in the neural response associated with changing the presented stimuli, researchers are attempting to index regions and their processing biases along perceptual, conceptual and response dimensions.<ref name="Grill-Spector & Malach 2001">{{cite journal|last1=Grill-Spector|first1=K|last2=Malach|first2=R|title=fMR-adaptation: a tool for studying the functional properties of human cortical neurons|journal=Acta Psychologia|date=2001|volume=107|issue=1|pages=293–321|doi=10.1016/s0001-6918(01)00019-1}}</ref> This area of research is based on multiple measurement methods from single cell recordings<ref name=Sobotka>{{cite journal|last1=Sobotka|first1=S|last2=Ringo|first2=J.L|title=Stimulus specific adaptation in excited but not in inhibited cells in inferotemporal cortex of macaque|journal=Brain Research|date=1994|volume=646|pages=95–99|doi=10.1016/0006-8993(94)90061-2}}</ref> to multi-regional measurements using [[functional magnetic resonance imaging]] (fMRI),<ref name="Buckner & Koustaal">{{cite journal|last1=Buckner|first1=R.L|last2=Koustaal|first2=W|title=Functional neuroimaging studies of encoding, priming, and explicit memory retrieval|journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A.|date=1998|volume=95|pages=891–898|doi=10.1073/pnas.95.3.891|pmc=33813}}</ref> [[electroencephalography]] (EEG)<ref name=Schendan>{{cite journal|last1=Schendan|first1=H.E|last2=Kutas|first2=M|title=Time course of processes and representations supporting visual object identification and memory|journal=Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience|date=2003|volume=15|pages=111–135|doi=10.1162/089892903321107864|pmid=12590847}}</ref> and [[magnetoencephalography]] (MEG).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gilbert|first1=J|title=Top-down modulation during object priming: evidence from MEG|journal=Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience|date=2005|volume=Supplement|page=132}}</ref> [[Transcranial magnetic stimulation]] (TMS) has also been used to temporarily 'lesion' (inactivate) specific regions and so get an indication of the necessity of those regions in processing specific dimensions of the presented stimuli.<ref name="Pobric 2007">{{cite journal|last1=Pobric|first1=G|last2=Schweinberger|first2=S.R|last3=Lavidor|first3=M|title=Magnetic stimulation of the right visual cortex impairs form-specific priming|journal=Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience|date=2007|volume=19|issue=6|pages=1013–1020|doi=10.1162/jocn.2007.19.6.1013|pmid=17536971}}</ref> Much of this research has been focused on the visual domain, however auditory<ref name="Gagnepain 2008">{{cite journal|last1=Gagnepain|first1=P|last2=Chételat|first2=G|last3=Landeau|first3=B|last4=Dayan|first4=J|last5=Eustache|first5=F|last6=Lebreton|first6=K|title=Spoken word memory traces within the human auditory cortex revealed by repetition priming and functional magnetic resonance imaging|journal=The Journal of Neuroscience|date=2008|volume=28|issue=20|pages=5281–5289|doi=10.1523/jneurosci.0565-08.2008|pmid=18480284}}</ref> and olfactory<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Olsson|first1=M.J|title=Implicit testing of odor memory: instances of positive and negative repetition priming|journal=Chemical Senses|date=1999|volume=24|issue=3|pages=347–350|doi=10.1093/chemse/24.3.347}}</ref> processes have also been investigated.
== Theories and models == Numerous models have been put forward to explain behavioural efficiencies that are gained with repeated presentations of the same or similar stimuli. These are outlined below.
===''Fatigue''=== In this model the attenuation of a neural response is hypothesised to be due to an overall reduction in the [[amplitude]] of a neuron's firing.<ref name=Kohn>{{cite journal|last1=Kohn|first1=A|last2=Movshon|first2=J.A|title=Neuronal adaptation to visual motion in area MT of the macaque|journal=Neuron|date=2003|volume=39|issue=4|pages=681–691|doi=10.1016/s0896-6273(03)00438-0}}</ref> Whether this reduction occurs across all neurons that responded to the initial stimulus or just the critical subset of those that initially responded maximally, is still unclear.<ref name="Grill-Spector 2006">{{cite journal|last1=Grill-Spector|first1=K|last2=Henson|first2=R|last3=Martin|first3=A|title=Repetition and the brain: neural models of stimulus-specific effects|journal=Trends in Cognitive Sciences|date=2006|volume=10|issue=1|pages=14–23|doi=10.1016/j.tics.2005.11.006}}</ref> However, evidence does suggest that a mechanism like this reduces redundant neural firing and enhances efficiencies in processing in the early visual cortex.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dragoi|first1=V|last2=Sharma|first2=J|last3=Miller|first3=E.K|last4=Sur|first4=M|title=Dynamics of neuronal sensitivity in visual cortex and local feature discrimination|journal=Nature Neuroscience|date=2002|volume=5|issue=9|pages=883–891|doi=10.1038/nn900}}</ref>
===''Sharpening''=== Along similar lines is the idea that repetition causes the neurons that are less relevant to the representation of the stimulus to stop firing when that stimulus is repeated.<ref name=Wiggs&Martin>{{cite journal|last1=Wiggs|first1=C.L|last2=Martin|first2=A|title=Properties and mechanisms of perceptual priming|journal=Current Opinion in Neurobiology|date=1998|volume=8|pages=227–233|doi=10.1016/s0959-4388(98)80144-x}}</ref> In this way the representation is supported by a gradually sparser response, resulting in an adaptive reduction in metabolic requirements and increased efficiencies in information transmission through the neural hierarchy.<ref name="Grill-Spector 2006" /> This could be the result of lateral inhibition within representational levels in a competitive [[Hebbian]] learning system, where strong connections get stronger and inhibit the weaker connections.<ref name="Grill-Spector 2006" /> Much of the evidence for this comes from primate studies of the [[inferotemporal cortex]]<ref name=Freedman>{{cite journal|last1=Freedman|first1=D.J|last2=Riesenhuber|first2=M|last3=Poggio|first3=T|last4=Miller|first4=E.K|title=Experience-dependent sharpening of visual shape selectivity in inferior temporal cortex|journal=Cerebral Cortex|date=2006|volume=16|issue=11|pages=1631–1644|doi=10.1093/cercor/bhj100|pmid=16400159}}</ref> and single cell recordings with long training periods.<ref name=Sigala>{{cite journal|last1=Sigala|first1=N|last2=Logothetis|first2=N.K|title=Visual categorization shapes feature selectivity in the primate temporal cortex|journal=Nature|date=2002|volume=415|issue=6869|pages=318–320|doi=10.1038/415318a|pmid=11797008}}</ref> However, decreases in firing rate over short-term training on repeated stimuli appear to be greatest in those cells that initially respond with the highest activation rate,<ref name="Li miller desimone">{{cite journal|last1=Li|first1=L|last2=Miller|first2=E.K|last3=Desimone|first3=R|title=The representation of stimulus familiarity in anterior inferior temporal cortex|journal=Journal of Neurophysiology|date=1993|volume=69|issue=6|pages=1918–1929}}</ref> in line with the fatigue model above.
===''Facilitation''=== The key concept in this model is that information travels faster through the network when the current stimulus representation overlaps with a previous representation, driven by more rapid onset of neural activation with repeated presentations.<ref name="James & Gauthier 2006">{{cite journal|last1=James|first1=T.W|last2=Gauthier|first2=I|title=Repetition‐induced changes in BOLD response reflect accumulation of neural activity|journal=Human Brain Mapping|date=2006|volume=27|issue=1|pages=37–46|doi=10.1002/hbm.20165|pmid=15954142}}</ref> fMRI studies have been used in an attempt to measure these potential latency differences but the temporal resolution is not very precise<ref name="Gagnepain 2008" /> and single cell recordings typically do not show shortened latencies to repeated stimuli.<ref name=Pedreira>{{cite journal|last1=Pedreira|first1=C|last2=Mormann|first2=F|last3=Kraskov|first3=A|last4=Cerf|first4=M|last5=Fried|first5=I|last6=Koch|first6=C|last7=Quiroga|first7=R.Q|title=Responses of human medial temporal lobe neurons are modulated by stimulus repetition|journal=Journal of Neurophysiology|date=2010|volume=103|issue=1|pages=97–107|doi=10.1152/jn.91323.2008|pmid=19864436|pmc=2807242}}</ref> Another possible explanation of facilitation is synaptic potentiation within an [[attractor network|attractor neural network]] model where repetition decreases the settling time as the attractor basin deepens and so increases the overall speed of processing.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Becker|first1=S|last2=Moscovitch|first2=M|last3=Behrmann|first3=M|last4=Joordens|first4=S|title=Long-term semantic priming: a computational account and empirical evidence|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition|date=1997|volume=23|issue=5|pages=1059–1082|doi=10.1037/0278-7393.23.5.1059}}</ref>
===''Reduced prediction error/stimulus expectation''=== When a stimulus is repeated top-down feedback modulates the neural response of earlier processing regions,<ref name="Friston 2005">{{cite journal|last1=Friston|first1=K|title=A theory of cortical responses|journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences|date=2005|volume=360|issue=1456|pages=815–836|doi=10.1098/rstb.2005.1622|pmid=15937014|pmc=1569488}}</ref> with reduced neural activation and improved behavioural responses reflecting fulfilled expectations.<ref name=Summerfield /> The idea for this comes from [[predictive coding]] theories and Bayesian statistics<ref name="Rao & Ballard">{{cite journal|last1=Rao|first1=R.P|last2=Ballard|first2=D.H|title=Predictive coding in the visual cortex: a functional interpretation of some extra-classical receptive-field effects|journal=Nature Neuroscience|date=1999|volume=2|issue=1|pages=79–87|doi=10.1038/4580|pmid=10195184}}</ref> and has some support in fMRI studies manipulating stimulus expectation.<ref name=Summerfield /> However, the results may also reflect the involvement of attention, which seems to have a modulatory effect on the extent of priming elicited.<ref name=Larsson />
===''Neural synchrony''=== This theory is based on the idea that because downstream neurons are sensitive to both the firing rates and the timing of those inputs, efficiencies in processing may be gained through synchronised activation.<ref name="Gilbert Gotts Carver">{{cite journal|last1=Gilbert|first1=J.R|last2=Gotts|first2=S.J|last3=Carver|first3=F.W|last4=Martin|first4=A|title=Object repetition leads to local increases in the temporal coordination of neural responses|journal=Frontiers in Human Neuroscience|date=2010|volume=4|doi=10.3389/fnhum.2010.00030}}</ref> Evidence of synchronisation associated with repeated stimuli include phase locking found between two regions of the cat visual cortex while measuring spike synchronisation for trained compared with novel stimuli<ref name="von Stein">{{cite journal|last1=von Stein|first1=A|last2=Chiang|first2=C|last3=Konig|first3=P|title=Top-down processing mediated by interareal synchronization|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|date=2000|volume=97|pages=14748–14753|doi=10.1073/pnas.97.26.14748|pmid=11121074|pmc=18990}}</ref> and suppressed firing and increased synchrony of spikes with repetition of odour puffs to locust's antennae.<ref name=Stopfer>{{cite journal|last1=Stopfer|first1=M|last2=Laurent|first2=G|title=Short-term memory in olfactory network dynamics|journal=Nature|date=1000|volume=402|pages=664–668|doi=10.1038/45244|pmid=10604472}}</ref> Evidence using [[Electroencephalography|EEG]] and [[Magnetoencephalography|MEG]] suggests that stimulus repetition in humans results in increased synchrony between distinct cortical regions, often the same regions that show reduced local neural activity (see repetition suppression below).<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Ghuman|first=Avniel S.|last2=Bar|first2=Moshe|last3=Dobbins|first3=Ian G.|last4=Schnyer|first4=David M.|date=2008-06-17|title=The effects of priming on frontal-temporal communication|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|volume=105|issue=24|pages=8405–8409|doi=10.1073/pnas.0710674105|issn=1091-6490|pmc=2448849|pmid=18541919}}</ref><ref name="Gotts Chow & Martin">{{cite journal|last1=Gotts|first1=S.J|last2=Chow|first2=C.C|last3=Martin|first3=A|title=Repetition priming and repetition suppression: A case for enhanced efficiency through neural synchronization|journal=Cognitive Neuroscience|date=2012|volume=3|issue=4|pages=227–237|doi=10.1080/17588928.2012.670617|pmc=3491809}}</ref> In one study, the timing of this across-region synchronization predicted the amount of behavioral facilitation seen with repetition priming, suggestive of a close link between synchrony and behavior.<ref name=":0" />
===''Stimulus-response binding''=== This theory suggests that repetition priming is a result of binding the initial stimulus directly to the response while bypassing the intervening layers of computation.<ref name="Dobbins 2004">{{cite journal|last1=Dobbins|first1=I.G|title=Cortical activity reductions during repetition priming can result from rapid response learning|journal=Nature|date=2004|volume=428|pages=316–319|doi=10.1038/nature02400}}</ref> The mechanism mediating this direct binding has not been clarified but several hypotheses have been put forward. One theory explains it as a race between automatic activation of a previous stimulus-response route and the reengagement of the "algorithmic" route<ref name=Logan>{{cite journal|last1=Logan|first1=G.D|title=Repetition priming and automaticity: Common underlying mechanisms?|journal=Cognitive Psychology|date=1990|volume=22|issue=1|pages=1–35|doi=10.1016/0010-0285(90)90002-l}}</ref> and another theory suggests the operation of an "action-trigger" where repeated stimuli trigger the previous response through perceptual or conceptual associations with the original stimulus.<ref name=Kunde>{{cite journal|last1=Kunde|first1=W|title=Conscious control over the content of unconscious cognition|journal=Cognition|date=2003|volume=88|pages=223–242|doi=10.1016/s0010-0277(03)00023-4}}</ref> In support of this theory is evidence of a response congruency effect, which would be expected from these stimulus-response bindings.<ref name="Henson 2014">{{cite journal|last1=Henson|first1=R.N|last2=Eckstein|first2=D|last3=Waszak|first3=F|last4=Frings|first4=C|last5=Horner|first5=A.J|title=Stimulus–response bindings in priming|journal=Trends in Cognitive Sciences|date=2014|volume=18|issue=7|pages=376–384|doi=10.1016/j.tics.2014.03.004}}</ref> The increased synchrony between regions discussed above could be a neural correlate of stimulus-response binding.<ref name=":0" />
== Neural correlates ==
=== Repetition suppression === The phenomenon of ''repetition suppression'', a reduction in neural activity when stimuli are repeated, is thought to depend on processing overlaps between repeated items<ref name=Epstein>{{cite journal|last1=Epstein|first1=R.A|last2=Parker|first2=W.E|last3=Feiler|first3=A.M|title=Two kinds of fMRI repetition suppression? Evidence for dissociable neural mechanisms|journal=Journal of Neurophysiology|date=2008|volume=99|pages=2877–2886|doi=10.1152/jn.90376.2008|pmid=18400954}}</ref> and is generally considered to be the neural correlate of repetition priming. As such it has been used extensively in research investigating the nature of representations across various levels of the visual processing hierarchy.<ref name="Grill-Spector & Malach 2001" /> In doing so researchers have found that repetition suppression appears to occur on multiple processing levels; dependent on the stimuli being processed and the processing level at which the experimental manipulation is directed; with reductions in neural activity to repeated stimuli occurring in regions involved with the initial processing of those features.<ref name=Kristjansson>{{cite journal|last1=Kristjánsson|first1=Á|last2=Campana|first2=G|title=Where perception meets memory: A review of repetition priming in visual search tasks|journal=Attention, Perception, & Psychophysics|date=2010|volume=72|issue=1|pages=5–18|doi=10.3758/app.72.1.5}}</ref> However, care must be taken in interpreting the results of these studies as the relationship between repetition suppression and repetition priming has not been definitively established.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=McMahon|first1=D.B|last2=Olson|first2=C.R|title=Repetition suppression in monkey inferotemporal cortex: relation to behavioral priming|journal=Journal of Neurophysiology|date=2007|volume=97|issue=5|pages=3532–3543|doi=10.1152/jn.01042.2006|pmid=17344370}}</ref>
=== Repetition enhancement === Although repetition priming is most often associated with neural attenuation for repeated presentation of stimuli, increases in neural responses have also been measured in a number of experimental contexts. For example, when performing mathematical calculations,<ref name=Salimpoor>{{cite journal|last1=Salimpoor|first1=V.N|last2=Chang|first2=C|last3=Menon|first3=V|title=Neural basis of repetition priming during mathematical cognition: repetition suppression or repetition enhancement?|journal=Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience|date=2010|volume=22|issue=4|pages=790–805|doi=10.1162/jocn.2009.21234|pmc=4366146}}</ref> when repeated stimuli are degraded,<ref name="Horner & Henson 2008">{{cite journal|last1=Horner|first1=A.J|last2=Henson|first2=R.N|title=Priming, response learning and repetition suppression|journal=Neuropsychologia|date=2008|volume=46|issue=7|pages=1979–1991|doi=10.1016/j.neuropsychologia.2008.01.018}}</ref> in studies involving a backward masking paradigm<ref name="James & Gauthier 2006" /> and when stimuli have no pre-existing associations or meaning.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Henson|first1=R.N|last2=Shallice|first2=T|last3=Dolan|first3=R|title=Neuroimaging evidence for dissociable forms of repetition priming|journal=Science|date=2000|volume=287|issue=5456|pages=1269–1272|doi=10.1126/science.287.5456.1269}}</ref>

[[Transgender rights in Australia|Transgender]] and [[sex work rights]] advocacy | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Roberta Perkins''' (1949 – 26 June 2018) was an Australian [[sociologist]], writer, and [[transgender]] rights and [[sex worker]] rights activist. She wrote several books and multiple academic articles on the semi-nomadic lives of transgender sex workers, and established the first assistance center for transgender people in Australia. == Biography == Perkins completed her doctoral dissertation at [[Macquarie University]] in Sydney, in 1981. Her dissertation surveyed the lives and experiences of drag queens and transsexuals, and was one of the first ever doctoral works by an openly transgender woman.{{cite web |title=Roberta Perkins (1940–2018) sociologist, activist |url=https://zagria.blogspot.com/2018/07/roberta-perkins-1940-2018-sociologist.html |website=A Gender Variance Who's Who |accessdate=14 September 2018 |date=2 July 2018}} In the 1980s, she was an early member of the then newly-created Australian Transsexual Association, which supported trans people by lobbying for social and legal reform. In 1983, she published her first book, ''The Drag Queen Scene: Transsexuals in Kings Cross'', a survey of 146 drag queens based upon her dissertation. [[Frank Walker (Australian politician)|Frank Walker]], [[New South Wales]] [[Australian Labor Party|Labor]] Assembly person and at that time Minister for Youth and Community Services, read the book, and invited Perkins to meet. She told him about the poverty, homelessness and violence experienced by transgender sex workers, many of them youths; about the rape, beatings, harassment, and evictions, and how trans women could find no aid in either men's or women's shelters.[https://gendercentre.org.au/resources/news-affecting-the-community/item/vale-roberta-perkins-1940-2018 Roberta Perkins (1940–2018)], Katherine Cummings, June 2018. Retrieved 14 September 2018  Walker understood the gravity of the situation, and expressed his commitment to help. As a result, Perkins received a grant of AU$80,000 to open a center that would operate as a shelter for transgender sex workers. The home, originally called "Tiresias House", opened in Sydney with 12 beds, which were immediately filled. The center quickly grew, and within a few years included four houses, and had on permanent staff a registered nurse and a community worker. After six years, its name changed to the Gender Centre.[http://www.starobserver.com.au/news/national-news/trans-sex-worker-activist-roberta-perkins-mourned-community/169935 Trans Sex Worker Activist Roberta Perkins Mourned By Community], Jesse Jones, Star Observer, 28 June 2018. Retrieved 14 September 2018. Perkins left the Gender Centre in 1985, to concentrate on writing and publishing books and articles in academic publications about transgender women and sex workers. She was a noted figure in the struggle for [[sex worker rights]] in New South Wales and Australia as a whole. She was a founding member of the Australian Prostitutes Collective NSW, which advocated for [[decriminalization]] of sex work and for the improvement of sex workers' lives. The collective's work is continued today by the Sex Worker Outreach Project (SWOP) NSW.  Perkins died on 26 June 2018, at the age of 78. Her obituaries called her a "trail-blazer" and "a woman of action" who laid the groundwork for sex worker advocacy in her country, and benefited "countless" trans people and sex workers.  == Publications == * ''The Third Sex and Sanctified Persons: A Cross-Cultural Survey, Comparison and Analysis of Transvestism and Transsexuality''. '''The Sandars Readership in Bibliography''' is an annual lecture series given at Cambridge University. Instituted in 1895 at the behest of Mr Samuel Sandars of Trinity College (1837–1894), who left a £2000 bequest to the University, the series has continued down to the present day.<ref name=Readership>{{cite web |title=Sandars Readership in Bibliography |publisher=Cambridge University Library |date=2016 |accessdate=23 Dec 2016 |url=http://www.lib.cam.ac.uk/about-library/prizes-and-fellowships/sandars-readership-bibliography}}</ref> Together with the [[Panizzi Lectures]] at the [[British Library]] and the [[Lyell Lectures]] at [[Oxford University]], it is considered one of the major British bibliographical lecture series.<ref name="Bowman2012">{{cite book |author=Bowman, J.H. |title=British Librarianship and Information Work 2001–2005 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gfeiJ0SoeGAC&pg=PA157 |date=1 Oct 2012 |publisher=Ashgate |isbn=978-1-4094-8506-3 |page=157}}</ref>

{{italic title}} {{Taxobox | color = lightgrey | name = ''Candidatus'' Scalindua wagneri | image = | regnum = [[Bacteria]] | divisio = [[Planctomycetes]] | classis = Planctomycetia | ordo = [[Planctomycetales]] | familia = Brocadiceae | genus = ''[[Scalindua]]'' | species = ''wagneri'' | binomial = ''Candidatus'' Scalindua wagneri | binomial_authority = Schmid, ''et al.'' 2003. }}
''[[Candidatus]]'' '''Scalindua wagneri''' is a [[Gram-negative]] coccoid-shaped bacterium that was first isolated from a wastewater treatment plant.<ref name="Schmid 2003">{{cite journal|last1=Schmid|first1=Markus|last2=Walsh|first2=Kerry|last3=Webb|first3=Rick|last4=Rijpstra|first4=W. Irene|last5=van de Pas-Schoonen|first5=Katinka|last6=Verbruggen|first6=Mark Jan|last7=Hill|first7=Thomas|last8=Moffett|first8=Bruce|last9=Fuerst|first9=John|last10=Schouten|first10=Stefan|last11=Sinninghe Damsté|first11=Jaap S.|last12=Harris|first12=James|last13=Shaw|first13=Phil|last14=Jetten|first14=Mike|last15=Strous|first15=Marc|title=Candidatus "Scalindua brodae", sp. nov., Candidatus "Scalindua wagneri", sp. nov., Two New Species of Anaerobic Ammonium Oxidizing Bacteria|journal=Systematic and Applied Microbiology|date=January 2003|volume=26|issue=4|pages=529–538|doi=10.1078/072320203770865837|pmid=14666981}}</ref> This bacterium is an obligate [[anaerobic organism|anaerobic]] [[chemolithotroph]] that undergoes anaerobic ammonium oxidation ([[anammox]]).<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> It can be used in the wastewater treatment industry in nitrogen reactors to remove nitrogenous wastes from wastewater without contributing to fixed nitrogen loss and [[greenhouse gas]] emission.<ref name="Jetten 2004">{{Cite book|last1=Jetten|first1=Mike|last2=Schmid|first2=Markus|last3=Schmidt|first3=Ingo|last4=van Loosdrescht|first4=Mark|last5=Abma|first5=Wiebe|last6=Kuenen|first6=J. Gijs|last7=Mulder|first7=Jan-Willem|last8=Strous|first8=Marc|title=Biodiversity and application of anaerobic ammonium-oxidizing bacteria|journal=European Symposium on Environmental Biotechnology|date=2004|pages=21–26|url=https://books.google.com/?id=M196qh27KX0C&pg=PA21&lpg=PA21&dq=Biodiversity+and+application+of+anaerobic+ammonium-oxidizing+bacteria+European+Symposium+on+Environmental+Biotechnology#v=onepage&q=Biodiversity%20and%20application%20of%20anaerobic%20ammonium-oxidizing%20bacteria%20European%20Symposium%20on%20Environmental%20Biotechnology&f=false |accessdate=15 February 2016|isbn=9789058096531}}</ref>
==Characterization== ''Candidatus'' Scalindua wagneri is a [[coccus|coccoid]]-shaped bacterium with a diameter of 1 μm.<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> Like other [[Planctomycetes]], S. wagneri is [[Gram-negative]] and does not have [[peptidoglycan]] in its [[cell wall]].<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> In addition, the bacterium contains two inner membranes instead of having one inner membrane and one outer membrane that surrounds the cell wall.<ref name="van Niftrik 2004">{{cite journal|last1=van Niftrik|first1=Laura A.|last2=Fuerst|first2=John A.|last3=Damste|first3=Jaap S. Sinninghe|last4=Kuenen|first4=J. Gijs|last5=Jetten|first5=Mike S.M.|last6=Strous|first6=Marc|title=The anammoxosome: an intracytoplasmic compartment in anammox bacteria|journal=FEMS Microbiology Letters|date=April 2004|volume=233|issue=1|pages=7–13|doi=10.1016/j.femsle.2004.01.044|pmid=15098544}}</ref> Some of the near neighbors are other species within the new Scalindua genus, such as ''Candidatus'' S. sorokinii and ''Candidatus'' S. brodae.<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> Other neighbors include ''Candidatus'' Kuenenia stuttgartiensis and ''Candidatus'' [[Brocadia anammoxidans]].<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> S. wagneri and its genus share only about 85% similarity with other members in its evolutionary line, which suggests that it is distantly related to other anaerobic ammonium oxidizing (anammox) bacteria.<ref name="Schmid 2003" />
==Discovery== Markus Schmid from the Strous lab first discovered S. wagneri in a landfill [[leachate]] treatment plant located in [[Pitsea]], UK on August 1, 2001.<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> These bacteria doubled in number about every three weeks in laboratory conditions, which made them very difficult to isolate.<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> Therefore, the researchers used 16S [[rRNA]] ([[ribosomal RNA]]) gene analysis on the [[biofilm]] of wastewater samples to detect the presence of these bacteria.<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> They amplified and isolated the 16S rRNA gene from the biofilm using [[PCR]] and [[gel electrophoresis]]. Then, they [[TOPO cloning|cloned]] the DNA into TOPO [[Cloning vector|vectors]].<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> Once the researchers sequenced the DNA, they aligned the 16S rRNA gene sequences to a [[genome]] database and found that the sequences are related to the anammox bacteria.<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> One of the sequences showed a 93% similarity to ''Candidatus'' Scalindua sorokinii, which suggests that this sequence belonged to a new species within the genus Scalindua and the researchers named it ''Candidatus'' Scalindua wagneri after Michael Wagner, a microbial [[ecologist]].<ref name="Schmid 2003" />
==Metabolism== S. wagneri is an obligate [[anaerobic organism|anaerobic]] [[chemolithoautotroph]] and undergoes [[anaerobic ammonium oxidation]] (anammox) in the intracytoplasmic compartment called an [[anammox]]osome.<ref name="Schmid 2003" /><ref name="van Niftrik 2004" /> During the anammox process, [[ammonium]] is oxidized using [[nitrite]] as an [[electron acceptor]] and forms [[dinitrogen]] gas as a product.<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> It is proposed that this mechanism occurs through the production of a [[hydrazine]] intermediate using [[hydroxylamine]], which is derived from nitrite.<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> In addition, S. wagneri uses nitrite as an [[electron donor]] to fix [[carbon dioxide]] and forms [[nitrate]] as a byproduct.<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> To the test the [[metabolic]] properties of S. wagneri, Nakajima ''et al''. performed anammox activity tests using nitrogen compounds labeled with the <sup>15</sup>[[Isotopes of nitrogen#Nitrogen-15|N isotopes]] and measured <sup>28</sup>N<sub>2</sub>, <sup>29</sup>N<sub>2</sub>, and <sup>30</sup>N<sub>2</sub> concentrations after 15 days.<ref name="Nakajima 2008" /> The researchers found that the concentrations of the <sup>28</sup>N<sub>2</sub> and <sup>29</sup>N<sub>2</sub> gases increased significantly.<ref name="Nakajima 2008" /> These results suggest that ammonia and nitrite is used in equal amounts to make <sup>29</sup>N<sub>2</sub>, and [[denitrification]] concurrently occurs with anammox metabolism.<ref name="Nakajima 2008" />
==Genome== Currently, genomic information about S. wagneri is very limited.<ref name=NCBI /> Current genome sequences were collected from DNA isolated from the bacteria growing in a marine anammox bacteria (MAB) reactor.<ref name="Nakajima 2008" /> Then, the 16S rRNA genes on the DNA were amplified using a specific [[oligonucleotide]] [[Primer (molecular biology)|primer]] for ''Planctomycetales'', separated using gel electrophoresis, and sequenced using a CEQ 2000 DNA Sequencer.<ref name="Nakajima 2008">{{cite journal|last1=Nakajima|first1=J|last2=Sakka|first2=M|last3=Kimura|first3=T|last4=Furukawa|first4=K|last5=Sakka|first5=K| title=Enrichment of anammox bacteria from marine environment for the construction of a bioremediation reactor.|journal= Applied Microbiology and Biotechnology|date=2008|volume=77|issue=5|pages=1159–1166|doi=10.1007/s00253-007-1247-7|pmid=17965857}}</ref> Analysis of the 16S rRNA gene sequences was performed using the GENETYX program, and the alignments and phylogenetic trees were made using [[BLAST]], [[Clustal|CLUSTALW]] and [[neighbor joining]], respectively.<ref name="Nakajima 2008" /> To have a better understanding of the [[genome]], S. wagneri can be compared to one of its better-known relatives. For example, ''Candidatus'' Scalindua profunda has a genome length of 2.7 billion base pairs with a [[GC content]] of 39.1%.<ref name="Vossenberg 2013">{{cite journal|last1=van de Vossenberg|first1=Jack|last2=Woebken|first2=Dagmar|last3=Maalcke|first3=Wouter J.|last4=Wessels|first4=Hans J. C. T.|last5=Dutilh|first5=Bas E.|last6=Kartal|first6=Boran|last7=Janssen-Megens|first7=Eva M.|last8=Roeselers|first8=Guus|last9=Yan|first9=Jia|last10=Speth|first10=Daan|last11=Gloerich|first11=Jolein|last12=Geerts|first12=Wim|last13=van der Biezen|first13=Erwin|last14=Pluk|first14=Wendy|last15=Francoijs|first15=Kees-Jan|last16=Russ|first16=Lina|last17=Lam|first17=Phyllis|last18=Malfatti|first18=Stefanie A.|last19=Tringe|first19=Susannah Green|last20=Haaijer|first20=Suzanne C. M.|last21=Op den Camp|first21=Huub J. M.|last22=Stunnenberg|first22=Henk G.|last23=Amann|first23=Rudi|last24=Kuypers|first24=Marcel M. M.|last25=Jetten|first25=Mike S. M.|title=The metagenome of the marine anammox bacterium 'Scalindua profunda' illustrates the versatility of this globally important nitrogen cycle bacterium|journal=Environmental Microbiology|date=May 2013|volume=15|issue=5|pages=1275–1289|doi=10.1111/j.1462-2920.2012.02774.x|pmid=22568606|pmc=3655542}}</ref> There is no genomic information about the length or % GC content for S. wagneri. However, there are hundreds of 476 base pair partial sequences for its 16S rRNA gene.<ref name=NCBI>{{cite web|title=Scalindua wagneri|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/?term=scalindua%20wagneri|website=NCBI|publisher=NCBI|accessdate=10 March 2015}}</ref> Using [[fluorescent in situ hybridization]] (FISH) analysis, a technique used to detect specific DNA sequences on [[chromosomes]], researchers were not able to detect hybridization between the chromosome of S. wagneri and the putative anammox DNA probe.<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> This suggests that S. wagneri is not very similar to the known anammox bacteria, so the researchers categorized the bacterium into its own genus.<ref name="Schmid 2003" />
==Ecology== Although researchers are unable to isolate pure [[cultures]] of S. wagneri, it is believed to encompass a broad [[Ecological niche|niche]].<ref name="Li 2010" /> Using 16S rRNA gene analysis, Schmid first found evidence of the bacteria in wastewater treatment plants.<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> Other researchers also found 16S rRNA gene evidence in a petroleum reservoir held at a temperature range between 55 °C and 75 °C in addition to [[freshwater]] and [[Marine biology|marine]] [[ecosystems]], such as [[estuaries]].<ref name="Li 2010">{{cite journal|last1=Li|first1=Hui|last2=Chen|first2=Shuo|last3=Mu|first3=Bo-Zhong|last4=Gu|first4=Ji-Dong|title=Molecular Detection of Anaerobic Ammonium-Oxidizing (Anammox) Bacteria in High-Temperature Petroleum Reservoirs|journal=Microbial Ecology|date=26 August 2010|volume=60|issue=4|pages=771–783|doi=10.1007/s00248-010-9733-3|pmid=20740282|pmc=2974184}}</ref><ref name="Penton 2006">{{cite journal|last1=Penton|first1=C. R.|last2=Devol|first2=A. H.|last3=Tiedje|first3=J. M.|title=Molecular Evidence for the Broad Distribution of Anaerobic Ammonium-Oxidizing Bacteria in Freshwater and Marine Sediments|journal=Applied and Environmental Microbiology|date=4 October 2006|volume=72|issue=10|pages=6829–6832|doi=10.1128/AEM.01254-06|pmid=17021238|pmc=1610322}}</ref>
==Importance and useful applications== S. wagneri allows wastewater treatment plants to reduce operation costs while reducing the adverse effects of [[nitrification]] and [[denitrification]] on the environment.<ref name="Jetten 2004" /> These bacteria contribute to the development of new technologies for wastewater management by aiding in the efficient removal of [[Nitrogen#Nitrogen compounds|nitrogenous compounds]] in wastewater.<ref name="Schmid 2003" /> Usually, nitrogen reactors use both nitrification and denitrification to remove nitrogenous wastes.<ref name="Jetten 2004" /> These processes have high operation costs due to the continuous maintenance of [[aerobic organism|aerobic]] conditions in the reactor.<ref name="Jetten 2004" /> Denitrification also produces [[nitrous oxide]] (N<sub>2</sub>O), which is a greenhouse gas that is detrimental to the environment.<ref name="Hu 2013">{{cite journal|last1=Hu|first1=Z.|last2=Lotti|first2=T.|last3=de Kreuk|first3=M.|last4=Kleerebezem|first4=R.|last5=van Loosdrecht|first5=M.|last6=Kruit|first6=J.|last7=Jetten|first7=M. S. M.|last8=Kartal|first8=B.|title=Nitrogen Removal by a Nitritation-Anammox Bioreactor at Low Temperature|journal=Applied and Environmental Microbiology|date=15 February 2013|volume=79|issue=8|pages=2807–2812|doi=10.1128/AEM.03987-12|pmid=23417008|pmc=3623191|url=http://repository.tudelft.nl/islandora/object/uuid%3Aa102f66d-70b1-4a04-858a-a2c8a264378b/datastream/OBJ/view}}</ref> Production of N<sub>2</sub>O contributes to the loss of fixed nitrogen, which regulates the biological [[productivity]] of [[ecosystems]].<ref name="Wright 2012">{{cite journal|last1=Wright|first1=Jody J.|last2=Konwar|first2=Kishori M.|last3=Hallam|first3=Steven J.|title=Microbial ecology of expanding oxygen minimum zones|journal=Nature Reviews Microbiology|date=14 May 2012|volume=10|issue=6|pages=381–394|doi=10.1038/nrmicro2778|pmid=22580367}}</ref><ref name="Moore 2013">{{cite journal|last1=Moore|first1=C. M.|last2=Mills|first2=M. M.|last3=Arrigo|first3=K. R.|last4=Berman-Frank|first4=I.|last5=Bopp|first5=L.|last6=Boyd|first6=P. W.|last7=Galbraith|first7=E. D.|last8=Geider|first8=R. J.|last9=Guieu|first9=C.|last10=Jaccard|first10=S. L.|last11=Jickells|first11=T. D.|last12=La Roche|first12=J.|last13=Lenton|first13=T. M.|last14=Mahowald|first14=N. M.|last15=Marañón|first15=E.|last16=Marinov|first16=I.|last17=Moore|first17=J. K.|last18=Nakatsuka|first18=T.|last19=Oschlies|first19=A.|last20=Saito|first20=M. A.|last21=Thingstad|first21=T. F.|last22=Tsuda|first22=A.|last23=Ulloa|first23=O.|title=Processes and patterns of oceanic nutrient limitation|journal=Nature Geoscience|date=31 March 2013|volume=6|issue=9|pages=701–710|doi=10.1038/ngeo1765|citeseerx=10.1.1.397.5625}}</ref> By inoculating wastewater reactors with the [[anaerobic organism|anaerobic]] S. wagneri, operation costs can be reduced by about ninety percent without the production of greenhouse gases.<ref name="Jetten 2004" /> This allows for better wastewater management in a more cost-efficient manner without contributing to [[climate change]].<ref name="Jetten 2004" /><ref name="Hu 2013" />

{{orphan|date=October 2012}} '''Standard time''' is the amount of time that should be allowed for an average [[worker]] to process one [[work unit]] using the standard method and working at a normal pace. The standard time includes some additional time, called the [[contingency allowance]], to provide for the worker's personal needs, [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]], and unavoidable delays during the shift.
== Prerequisite for Valid Time Standards == *The task is performed by an average worker *The worker's pace represents standard performance *The worker uses the standard method *The task is performed on a standard work unit
== Calculating the Standard Time ==
The standard time (Ts) is calculated from multiplying the observed time (To) by the performance rating (R) and the personal need, fatigue and unavoidable delays (PFD): Ts = To*R*(1+PFD)
== Usages for Standard Time == *Estimate the quantity of the production *Determine workforce size and equipment requirement *Compare alternative methods *Evaluate worker's performance *Plan and schedule production and estimate costs
==Further reading== *''Work Systems: The Methods, Measurement & Management of Work'' by Mikell P. Groover, Prentice-Hall (2006) {{ISBN|0-13-140650-7}} *''Work Measurement and Methods Improvement'' by Lawrence S. Aft, Wiley (2000) {{ISBN|0-471-37089-4}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Standard Time In Manufacturing}} [[Category:Industrial engineering]]

In [[engineering]], '''technical peer review''' is a type of engineering review. Technical peer reviews are a well defined review process for finding and fixing defects, conducted by a team of peers with assigned roles. Technical peer reviews are carried out by peers representing areas of life cycle affected by material being reviewed (usually limited to 6 or fewer people). Technical peer reviews are held within development phases, between milestone reviews, on completed products or completed portions of products.<ref name = "NASA-6105">{{cite book| title=NASA Systems Engineering Handbook| id=SP-610S | year=2007|publisher=[[NASA]]|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20080008301_2008008500.pdf}} </ref>
A technical peer review may also be called a ''engineering peer review'', a ''product peer review'', a ''peer review/inspection'' or an ''inspection.''
== Overview == The purpose of technical peer reviews is to remove defects as early as possible in the development process. By removing defects at their origin (e.g., requirements and design documents, test plans and procedures, software code, etc.), technical peer reviews prevent defects from propagating through multiple phases and work products, and reduce the overall amount of rework necessary on projects.
In addition, improved team efficiency is a side effect of technical peer reviews (e.g., by improving team communication, integrating the viewpoints of various engineering specialty disciplines, more quickly bringing new members up to speed, and educating project members about effective development practices).
In [[CMMI]], peer reviews are used as a principal means of verification in the Verification process area and as an objective evaluation method in the Process and Product Quality Assurance process area. The results of technical peer reviews can be reported at milestone reviews. (See [[Milestone (project management)]].)
==Roles of participants== ;Moderator Responsible for conducting the technical peer review process and collecting inspection data. Plays key role in all stages of the technical peer review process except rework. Required to perform several duties during a technical peer review in addition to inspector’s tasks.
;Inspectors Responsible for finding defects in work product from a general point of view, as well as defects that affect their area of expertise.
;Author Provides information about work product during all stages of process. Responsible for correcting all major defects and any minor and trivial defects that cost and schedule permit. Performs duties of an inspector.
;Reader Guides team through work product during the technical peer review meeting. Reads or paraphrases work product in detail. Performs duties of an inspector in addition to reader’s role.
;Recorder Accurately records each defect found during inspection meeting on the Inspection Defect List. Performs duties of an inspector in addition to recorder’s role.
== Vested interest of reviewers == There are two philosophies about the vested interest of the inspectors in the product under review. On one hand, project personnel who have a vested interest in the work product under review have the most knowledge of the product and are motivated to find and fix defects. On the other hand, personnel from outside the project who do not have a vested interest in the work product bring objectivity and a fresh viewpoint to the technical peer review team.
Each inspector is invited to disclose vested interests to the rest of the technical peer review panel so the Moderator can exercise sound judgement in evaluating the inspector's inputs.
== Distinction from other types of technical review == Peer reviews are distinct from management reviews, which are conducted by management representatives rather than by colleagues, and for management and control purposes rather than for technical evaluation. They are also distinct from [[software audit review]]s, which are conducted by personnel external to the project, to evaluate compliance with specifications, standards, contractual agreements, or other criteria.
A [[software peer review]] is a type of technical peer review. The [[IEEE]] defines formal structures, roles, and processes for software peer reviews.<ref>[[IEEE]] Std. 1028-1997, "IEEE Standard for Software Reviews"</ref>
== Management involvement == Management representatives are typically not involved in the conduct of a peer review. This is especially true of line managers of the author or other participants in the review. A policy of encouraging management to stay out of peer reviews encourages the peer review team to concentrate on the product being reviewed and not on the people or personalities involved.
== Detailed instructions == For detailed instructions on conducting a technical peer review/inspection, see NASA Systems Engineering Handbook, Appendix N.<ref name = "NASA-6105"/>
== See also == *[[Design review]] - encompasses preliminary, critical and other design reviews

{{short description|Citation style that uses numbers within the text to cite references}} The '''Vancouver system''', also known as '''Vancouver reference style''' or the '''author–number system''', is a [[citation]] style that uses numbers within the text that refer to numbered entries in the reference list. It is popular in the [[physical sciences]] and is one of two referencing systems normally used in medicine, the other being the [[Harvard referencing|author–date, or "Harvard", system]].<ref name="BMA">{{vcite web|title=Reference styles|url=https://www.bma.org.uk/library/library-guide/reference-styles|date=|accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | title = International Committee of Medical Journal Editors (ICMJE) Uniform Requirements for Manuscripts Submitted to Biomedical Journals: Sample References | url = https://www.nlm.nih.gov/bsd/uniform_requirements.html | publisher = [[United States National Library of Medicine]] | date = | accessdate = 2013-03-01 }}</ref> Vancouver style is used by [[MEDLINE]] and [[PubMed]].<ref name="Citing_Medicine">{{Citation |last=Patrias |first=Karen |editor-last=Wendling |editor-first=Dan |title=Citing Medicine: The NLM Style Guide for Authors, Editors, and Publishers |publisher=[[United States National Library of Medicine]] |location=[[Bethesda, Maryland]], USA |url=https://www.nlm.nih.gov/citingmedicine |postscript=. | name-list-format = vanc }}</ref>
Hundreds of [[scientific journals]] use author-number systems. They all follow the same essential logic (that is, numbered citations pointing to numbered list entries), although the trivial details of the output mask, such as [[punctuation]], [[letter case#Case styles|casing of titles]], and [[italic type|italic]], vary widely among them. They have existed for over a century; the names "Vancouver system" or "Vancouver style" have existed since 1978. The latest version of the latter is ''[[Citing Medicine]]'', per the ''References > Style and Format'' section of the ICMJE Recommendations.<ref name=icmje-recommendations>{{Citation |author=ICMJE |title=Recommendations for the Conduct, Reporting, Editing, and Publication of Scholarly Work in Medical Journals |url=http://www.icmje.org/icmje-recommendations.pdf |postscript=.}}</ref>
In the broad sense, the Vancouver system refers to any author-number system regardless of the formatting details. A narrower definition of the Vancouver system refers to a specific author-number format specified by the [[ICMJE Recommendations]] (Uniform Requirements for Manuscripts, URM). For example, the [[AMA Manual of Style|AMA reference style]] is Vancouver style in the broad sense because it is an author-number system that conforms to the URM, but not in the narrow sense because its formatting differs in some minor details from the NLM/PubMed style (such as what is italicized and whether the citation numbers are bracketed).
==History== Author–number systems have existed for over a century and throughout that time have been one of the main types of [[citation]] style in [[scientific journal]]s (the other being [[parenthetical referencing|author–date]]). In 1978, a committee of editors from various [[medical journal]]s, the International Committee of Medical Journal Editors (ICMJE), met in [[Vancouver|Vancouver, BC, Canada]] to agree to a unified set of requirements for the articles of such journals. This meeting led to the establishment of the [[Uniform Requirements for Manuscripts Submitted to Biomedical Journals]] (URMs). Part of the URMs is the reference style, for which the ICMJE selected the long-established author–number principle.
The URMs were developed 15 years before the [[World Wide Web]] debuted. During those years, they were published as articles or supplements in various ICMJE member journals. These included the 1991 BMJ publication,<ref>{{vcite journal |pmid=2001512 |pmc=1669007 |year=1991 |month=Feb |title=Uniform requirements for manuscripts submitted to biomedical journals. | author = International Committee of Medical Journal Editors |volume=302 |issue=6772 |pages=338–341 |issn=0959-8138 |journal=BMJ (Clinical research ed.) |doi=10.1136/bmj.302.6772.338}}</ref> the 1995 ''[[CMAJ]]'' publication<ref>{{vcite journal |pmid=7728695 |pmc=1337910 |year=1995 |month=May |title=Uniform requirements for manuscripts submitted to biomedical journals. | author = International Committee of Medical Journal Editors |volume=152 |issue=9 |pages=1459–1473 |issn=0820-3946 |journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal}}</ref> and the 1997 ''[[Annals of Internal Medicine]]'' publication.<ref>{{vcite journal |pmid=8992922 |year=1997 |month=Jan |title=Uniform requirements for manuscripts submitted to biomedical journals. |author=International Committee of Medical Journal Editors |volume=126 |issue=1 |pages=36–47 |issn=0003-4819 |journal=Annals of Internal Medicine |url=http://www.annals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=8992922 |format=Free full text |doi=10.7326/0003-4819-126-1-199701010-00006}}</ref> In the late 1990s and early 2000s, journals were asked to cite the 1997 ''[[JAMA (journal)|JAMA]]'' version<ref>{{vcite journal |pmid=9062335 |year=1997 |month=Mar |title=Uniform requirements for manuscripts submitted to biomedical journals. | author = International Committee of Medical Journal Editors |volume=277 |issue=11 |pages=927–934 |issn=0098-7484 |journal=JAMA: The Journal of the American Medical Association |doi=10.1001/jama.277.11.927}}</ref> when reprinting the ''Uniform requirements''.
In the early 2000s, with the Web having become a major force in academic life, the idea gradually took hold that the logical home for the latest edition of the URMs would be the [http://www.icmje.org/ ICMJE website] itself (as opposed to whichever journal article or supplement had most recently published an update). For example, as of 2004, the editors of ''[[Haematologica]]'' decided simply to invite their authors to visit www.icmje.org for the 2003 revision of the ''Uniform requirements''.<ref>{{vcite journal |pmid=15020262 |year=2004 |month=Mar |author=International Committee Of Medical Journal Editors (ICMJE) |title=Uniform Requirements for Manuscripts Submitted to Biomedical Journals: writing and editing for biomedical publication |volume=89 |issue=3 |pages=264 |issn=0390-6078 |journal=Haematologica |url=http://www.haematologica.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=15020262 |format=Free full text}}</ref>
Since the early to mid-2000s, the [[United States National Library of Medicine]] (which runs [[MEDLINE]] and [[PubMed]]) has hosted the ICMJE's "Sample References" pages.<ref>{{vcite web |url=https://www.nlm.nih.gov/bsd/uniform_requirements.html |author = International Committee of Medical Journal Editors | title = Uniform Requirements for Manuscripts Submitted to Biomedical Journals: Sample References | accessdate = 2006-12-24 }}</ref> Around 2007, the NLM created ''[[Citing Medicine]]'', its [[style guide]] for citation style, as a new home for the style's details. The ICMJE Recommendations now point to ''[[Citing Medicine]]'' as the home for the formatting details of Vancouver style.<ref name=icmje-recommendations/> For example, in the December 2013 edition of the ICMJE Recommendations, the relevant paragraph is IV.A.3.g.ii. (''References > Style and Format'').<ref name=icmje-recommendations/>
==Sample usage==
===Labelling citations=== References are numbered consecutively in order of appearance in the text – they are identified by [[Arabic numerals]] in [[Bracket#Parentheses ( )|parentheses]]''' (1)''', [[square brackets]]''' [1]''', [[superscript]]'''<sup>1</sup>''', or a combination'''<sup>[1]</sup>'''. The number usually appears at the end of the material it supports, and an entry in the reference list would give full bibliographical information for the source:
{{quote|Blood loss and the number of patients requiring post-operative blood transfusions were significantly greater, but operation and fluoroscopy times were significantly shorter, for the DHS versus the PFNA group<sup>[1]</sup>.}}
And the entry in the reference list would be: 1. {{cite journal|vauthors=Xu YZ, Geng DC, Mao HQ, Zhu XS, Yang HL|title=A comparison of the proximal femoral nail antirotation device and dynamic hip screw in the treatment of unstable pertrochanteric fracture.|pmid=20925999|journal=J Int Med Res|date=2010|volume=38|pages=1266–1275}}
===Placing citations=== Several descriptions of the Vancouver system say that the number can be placed ''outside'' the text punctuation to avoid disruption to the flow of the text, ''or'' be placed ''inside'' the text punctuation, and that there are different cultures in different traditions.<ref name="url_Leicester">{{vcite web | url = http://www2.le.ac.uk/library/help/citing/vancouver-numbered-system | title = Vancouver (Numbered) System | publisher = University of Leicester }}</ref><ref name="urlmedind.nic.in">{{vcite web | url = http://medind.nic.in/jbc/t04/i1/jbct04i1p21.pdf | title = Reference systems deciphered for you | publisher = Department of Forensic Medicine, Govt. Medical College, Patiala }}</ref> The first method is recommended by some universities and colleges,<ref name="urllibrary.vcc.ca">{{vcite web | url = http://library.vcc.ca/downloads/VCC_VancouverStyleGuide.pdf | title = Vancouver Citation Style | publisher = Vancouver Community College | quote = The citation in brackets is placed after any commas and periods, and before any colons and semi-colons | accessdate = 2015-01-05 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150209043418/http://library.vcc.ca/downloads/VCC_VancouverStyleGuide.pdf | archivedate = 2015-02-09 | deadurl = yes | df = }}</ref> while the latter method is required by scientific publications such as the [[The MLA Style Manual|MLA]]<ref name="urlMLA Citation Style | Cornell University Library">{{vcite web | url = https://www.library.cornell.edu/research/citation/mla | title = MLA Citation Style | publisher = Cornell University Library }}</ref> and [[IEEE]]<ref name=IEEE/> except for in the end of a block quotation. (IEEE are using Vancouver style labels within brackets, for example [1] to cite the first reference in the list, but otherwise refer to [[Chicago Style Manual]].)<ref name=IEEE>{{vcite web | url = http://www.ieee.org/documents/ieeecitationref.pdf | title = IEEE Citation Reference | format = | work = IEEE | quote = References ... appear on the line, in square brackets, inside the punctuation. | accessdate = 2011-05-12 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110408195511/http://www.ieee.org/documents/ieeecitationref.pdf | archivedate = 2011-04-08 | deadurl = yes | df = }}</ref> The original Vancouver system documents (the [[ICMJE recommendations]] and Uniform Requirements for Manuscripts Submitted to Biomedical Journals) do not discuss placement of the citation mark.
===Format of citations=== Different formats exist for different types of sources, e.g. books, journal articles etc. Author names are abbreviated to at most two initials.<ref>{{vcite book |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK7282/ |title=Citing Medicine: The NLM Style Guide for Authors, Editors, and Publishers [Internet] | edition=2nd | first = K | last = Patrias | editor-first = D | editor-last = Wendling |location=Bethesda, MD | publisher = National Library of Medicine (US) | year = 2007 | accessdate = 2012-02-22 | quote = Convert given (first) names and middle names to initials, for a maximum of two initials following each surname | name-list-format = vanc }}</ref> Although ''Citing Medicine'' does not explicitly mandate merging initials (e.g. "R. K." would be merged into "RK"), the examples used throughout the book do.
====Journal articles====
=====Standard journal articles===== * Leurs R, Church MK, Taglialatela M. H<sub>1</sub>-antihistamines: inverse agonism, anti-inflammatory actions and cardiac effects. Clin Exp Allergy. 2002 Apr;32(4):489-498. * Tashiro J, Yamaguchi S, Ishii T, Suzuki A, Kondo H, Morita Y, Hara K, Koyama I. Inferior oncological prognosis of surgery without oral chemotherapy for stage III colon cancer in clinical settings. World J Surg Oncol. 2014 May 10;12(1):145. [Epub ahead of print]
As an option, if a journal carries continuous pagination throughout a volume (as many medical journals do), the month and issue number may be omitted.
* Thomas MC. Diuretics, ACE inhibitors and NSAIDs – the triple whammy. Med J Aust. 2000;172:184-185.
The [[National Library of Medicine|NLM]] lists all authors for all articles, because it is appropriate for capturing all authors and all of their publications in the MEDLINE database to be found by searches. However, in the reference lists of articles, most journals truncate the list after 3 or 6 names, followed by "[[et al.]]" (which most medical journals do not italicize):
* Guilbert TW, Morgan WJ, Zeiger RS, Mauger DT, Boehmer SJ, Szefler SJ, et al. Long-term inhaled corticosteroids in preschool children at high risk for asthma. N Engl J Med. 2006 May 11;354(19):1985-1997.
Optionally, a unique identifier (such as the article's [[digital object identifier|DOI]] or [[PubMed#PubMed identifier|PMID]]) may be added to the citation:
* von Itzstein M, Wu WY, Kok GB, Pegg MS, Dyason JC, Jin B, et al. Rational design of potent sialidase-based inhibitors of influenza virus replication. Nature. 1993 Jun 3;363(6428):418-423. {{PMID|8502295}}.
NLM elides ending page numbers and uses a hyphen as the range indicating character (184-5). Some journals do likewise, whereas others expand the ending page numbers in full (184-185), use an en dash instead of a hyphen (184–5), or both (184–185).
Virtually all medical journal articles are published online. Many are published online only, and many others are published online ahead of print. For the date of online publication, at the end of the citation NLM puts "[Epub Year Mon Day]" (for online-only publication) or "[Epub ahead of print]" for online ahead of print (with the month and day following the year in its normal position). In contrast, [[AMA style]] puts "[published online Month Day, Year]" at the end of the article title. It no longer uses the term "Epub" and no longer includes the words "ahead of print". It omits the year from its normal location after the journal title abbreviation if there is no print data to give (online-only publication).
The titles of journals are abbreviated. There are no periods in the abbreviation. A period comes after the abbreviation, delimiting it from the next field. The abbreviations are standardized. The standardization was formerly incomplete and internal to organizations such as NLM. It is now formalized at the [[supraorganization]]al level by documents including [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK7251/ ''Citing Medicine'' at Appendix A: Abbreviations for Commonly Used English Words in Journal Titles], [[American National Standards Institute|ANSI]] Z39.5, [[ISO 4|ISO 4: Information and documentation -- Rules for the abbreviation of title words and titles of publications]], and the [http://www.issn.org/services/online-services/access-to-the-ltwa/ ISSN.org List of Title Word Abbreviations (LTWA)].
=====Articles not in English===== As per journal articles in English:
* Forneau E, Bovet D. Recherches sur l'action sympathicolytique d'un nouveau dérivé du dioxane. Arch Int Pharmacodyn. 1933;46:178-191. French.
The [[National Library of Medicine|NLM]] adds an English translation of the title enclosed in square brackets right after the title. The language is specified in full after the location (pagination), followed by a period.<!-- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK7282/box/A33262/?report=objectonly -->
